div.head: To the mot ILLUSTRIOUS D. JOHN CAPELLANUS, Councellour to the mot Chritian KING.
div.p:
THis Treatie, which five Years ince, I willingly Dedicated to You in the French Idiome, is now again preented to Your elf, replenihed with many Obervations in the Latine Tongue: eeing that by the great eteem of Your Name, our French Edition was not only Candidly accepted in France; but alo in other Forreign Nations among Learned Men: The exceeding happy ucces of which, had wrought in me an Admiration, had not the fame of Your Trancendant Learning made it Immortal, by your mot
Learned Writings, known, and throughly conidered by me. You being o well vered in all kind of Studies, that the mot Illutrious Ludovicus XIV, King of France and Navarre, made You the Mecaenas, or Cheriher of mot Learned men. Since it is o, I may remember the former Edition, and o much the rather, eeing that the Heer Duyst van Voorhout, a Man of an excellent Genious, made me as certain of Your Peculiar Favours towards me, as Your own frequent Honouring me with your Epitles: Wherefore with all Humility I crave, that even as You protected the former Edition, under the Shield of Your Authority, o You would vouchafe alo to protect This. Sir, The doing of which, will oblige him in the highet Nature, who is, and will be, during his Life, the Adorer of Your Replendent Name.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
IN the Year 1663. in the niverity of Leyden, I hearing the mot Famous, and Indefatigable Man in Studies, Francis de le Boe-Sylvius, daily teaching concerning the Pancreatick Juyce, to be one of the chiefet Foundations of Phyick, I endeavoured to find out that, hitherto undicovered Juyce; the which when I had done, and indeed after that manner which he had firt decribed to us; he having undertanding thereof, with all Diligence did incite me to Print thoe things, which I had oberved worthy of Notice, concerning this Subject, through divere Diections of various Animals: And I, willing to gratifie his Requet, publihed a little Treatie, concerning the Nature, and Office of the Pancreatick Juyce; which, although in an unpolihed manner, nevertheles, it o took with the Curious Indagators of Nature, that in a hort time, ufficient Examples of that Nature, were deired of me: For which caue, in the Year 1666, I publihed, at paris, this little Treatie, in the French Tongue; which, three or four Months
together, I preented to the Famous Dr. Bourdelot, to be publickly examined; to whoe Houe the mot Curious Wits of the niverity do frequently reort. And I, eeing that this econd Edition wonderfully took with the mot Learned Phyitians of all France, who have their Colledge at Paris, and returning to my own Country, I found that there were remaining no Coppies of my Firt Edition, being intigated by the Printer, and my Friends, for their akes who undertood not the French Tongue, have again turned the ame little Treatie into Latine, and that not barely, but in everal places have inerted new Obervations, and reolves to everal Objections, put to me againt this Treatie, both in France, and other Countries, that my Opinion might not eem, in any Repect, to be faulty; So that, the Treatie, which I now publih, may bear the name of a new one; which I hope, will not be unacceptable to the Reader. But eeing no writing (as Plato aith) can be o exact, that it may avoid the Cenures of Criticks, without doubt, there will be Carpers, who are better affected with Brawlings, and Drinkings, than the Diections of Bodies, which will laugh at me, for the pending o much time in the dicovery of this Juyce: But Hippocrates, in an Epitle to Damagetus, hath taught me in an Hitory of Democritus, that thoe Gibeings ought not to be regarded, &c. So much of which Hitory, as mot nearly appertaines to us, I will briefly relate: Democritus, inferiour to none of the Abderitans, when, to find out the nature of the
Bile, had betaken himelf, apart from the City, and there alone had diected many Animals; he was generally reputed to be mad; wherefore the Senate, and People of the Abderitans being ad, and troubled, did very much importune the Prince of Phyitians, that he would vouchafe to come, and cure the madnes of Democritus: Hippocrates, by the Merits of Democritus, and the Intreaties of the Abderitans, taking Ship went to Abderis, where he found all the Citizens, and Inhabitants gathered together, waiting for him without the Gates; part of whom running before, and part following, led Hippocrates to a high Hill without the City, (crying out ave, help, heal,) that he might ee the Madnes of Democritus: From whence they aw Democritus ometimes diecting Animals, ometimes mueing, and ometimes writing. Hippocrates, going all alone to Democritus, and making an exact tryal of him, although then he undertood he was not mad, asked him what he wrote there? Democritus anwered concerning Madnes; And being further asked, What he wrote of Madnes? aid, What ele, than what it is, and how generated, and how allayed in the Bodies of Men? For, thee Animals, which you ee here, that I open for this purpoe, is not becaue I hate the Works of God, but earch out the Nature and Seat of the Bile: For, you know, this is the caue of Mens Madnes, &c. Which being undertood, aith Hippocrates, Democritus in truth, I call God to witnes, you peak truly, and wiely:
And he, returning to the Abderitans, who waited for him at ome ditance, commended Democritus, and accued themelves of Madnes. I wih Hippocrates, the great Prince of Phyitians, might rie from the Dead, he would not blame thoe les, which deride me for my more diligent earch of the Pancreatick Juyce, than them which judged Democritus to be mad, for his exquiite enquiry into the Bile: Seeing that he thought them to be taught of God, which did not only tudy about Heat, Cold, Drynes, and Moiture, but about their Caues: For, it is not Heat (aith he) Lib. De Vet. Med. Text XXVI. XII. which hath great force, but Sharpnes, and Fluidity, and other things by me related. And he aith before Text XXIV. XX. Becaue there is in Man both bitter, alt, weet, acid, harp, and fluid, and infinite others, having all manner of Faculties, both of Plenty, and Strength. From whence he commonly calls thoe Faculties, and Powers he affirms Salt, Bitternes, and Acidity, with other things of the like Acrimony, to be commonly the caues of all Ditempers, as appears Lib. cap. Text XXV. From which it is as evident, as the Sun at Noon-day, that Hippocrates, if he were alive, would judge our Diections, and Searchings, about Salts, Acids, and other Faculties, ometimes abounding in the Pancreatick Juyce, to be highly neceary. In regard Hippocrates, and other of the Antients, who were famous in their time, were altogether ignorant of the Pancreatick Juyce; neither did they
undertand the whole depth of Nature; It is not to be imputed to them as a Fault: But on the contrary, thoe famous, and chiefet Guides of Widome, and Inciters of Wits, are to be commended; becaue they broke the Ice for us; and (as it is aid) thoe things which we read, were rightly invented, and oberved by them, are to be candidly embraced; and thoe things, which we really know to be fale, and erronious, I judge they ought to be corrected with uch Modety, as we deire thoe things, which we now write, hould be corrected with. If we conider a Thouand Years yet to come, omething may be found out, which will correct, and amend our Writings, by the unwearyed Searchers of Nature; for Arts admit of a daily Improvement, epecially in this age of ours, in which the Yoke of Authority being hook off, we may bring to the Tet thoe things which our Reaon and Sene doth afford us; for, the Enquirers into things Natural ought not to ditrut themelves, or o doubtfully to follow the teps of their Ancetors, as at any time, when they hall dicover Novelties, be afraid to publih them.

Antient times not all things knew:
For, Practis prang from Years more new.

div.p:
And as much as pertains to this Treatie,
of ours, which hath been o illutrated with daily Experience, new Obervations, and Reaons, that they who firt made a Quetion of the Truth of our Hypotheis, would be on our ide; or at leat confes, till now, never any Syteme was found out, in which fewer, or leer difficulties are, than this of ours, if they will but examine our Dictates without Prejudice, and Envy. Firt of all, Let the Reader be perwaded in himelf, that our Pancreatick Juyce is no Fictions, but a real Humour of our Bodies; and uch a one indeed as after its own eparation from the Blood, and Propulion, to the Intetines, is in a hort time after, again permixed with the Blood, eeing that all Liquid things, being carryed by the paage of the Guts, do eaily acend (by the Venae Lacteae) the firtThe Origin. is Thalamus. Treaury of the Living, and the lat of the Dead.

Which being granted, he may further conider it was not (by the Almighty God) ordained in vain, but for a common ue to the Body; and o all men will be eaily perwaded, that as often as the Pancreatick Juyce is rightly contituted, its ue doth naturally happen: And likewie when it happens preternaturally, then it is vitious, and preternatural: Seeing it is o, and my whole Treatie conits in the preerving a good Order of the Pancreatick Juyce, and amending it when vitiated, and helping Ditempers from thence ariing, we hope it will be very acceptable, and profitable to Practitioners: For, let this be its whole deigne, to give a helping
hand to all who profes Phyick, that they may ooner, afer, and more delightfully help the Calamities, and mieries of the Sick: And if I unhappily mis my aim, you may commend my Deigne, and modetly correct thoe things in which the weaknes of my Genious doth mitake: And if any one pleae to inform me better, I will allow him to convince me of my Errour, and not to accue me of Obtinacy, eeing that I am not moved by Ambition, but only deirous of finding out Truth, offer up thee my Studies unto you.

div.head: To the Right WORSHIPFUL Sr. CHRISTOPHER PACK, Kt. The Tranlator Dedicates thee His ENDEAVOURS.
div.p:
Cju
que ingenium non tatim emerget, Plin: nii Materiae, Fautor, occaio commendator
que contingat, Epit. 2 lib. 6. (aith the Learned Pliny) the Work and Ingenuity of every Peron doth not contantly proper well, unles the matter or occaion be remarkable, or ome worthy Patron happen to favour it.

As for the Matter, it hath already commended it elf to the World, and crowned the Learned Author thereof (throughout the European Diviion) with an honourable Acceptation, and Etimation, both in repect of the Invention, and Doctrinal Performances.

But in regard that I have aayed to make it more Univerally Intelligible, and Beneficial to Englih men, by putting it into our own Native Idiome, I conceive I ought to preent my Undertaking to the Patronage of ome worthy Peron; under the Protection of whoe Name,
it may have the freer paage through the World. To which end I have thought no Peron fitter than your worthy elf, both in repect of Your profound Judgment, and Favour to all things that may advance a Publick Good. Neither could I do les, if the Bonds of Gratitude be any Obligations to the minds of men, eeing (that next to my Parents) I tand more highly engaged to Your Worhip, than to any other Peron living; which hath been a great Motive and Inducement to this Preumption, which I hope Your Candour will pas by, and Candidly accept this mite from him who at the preent, is not capable of a better Retaliation of Your many Favours, than the humble offer of this Tranlation: The which, having been brought forth in Your Name, I knew not how it might better live than in Your Family; the kind apect of which, will not be only Amicable to it, but alo Honourable to him that is,

div.head: The TRANSLATOR to the READER.
div.p: I Having often viewed this Treatie of the mot ingenious D. Regnerus de Graaf, and many times alo heard it wihed for in Englih, at length Reolved to Tranlate it for their Sakes to whom the Original was not Communicable, in Regard of their Necience of the Language, though otherwie competently ingenious and intelligent. The which I am well atified will prove ervicable (and I hope alo acceptable to them) in three Repects.

Firt, that it will be of great tillity, for the more compleat undertanding the Works of the Learned Francicus Sylvius de le Boe that late Renowned Profeor of Phyick in the niverity of Leyden, the firt part of whoe Praxis is already in Englih; for in regard that he urgeth the Pancreatick Juice to be an Agent of Fermentation and Concoction of the Chyle, and
o conequently a contitutive part of the Blood, and Authour of many grievous Dieaes, and Enormities of the Body. It necearily follows 1. That the certainty of this Juyce ought to be known; that is, that it be a real Juyce, or Humour in all Mens Bodies, and not a thing only immaginary or uncertain, which this Author hath evidently demontrated. 2. The way and manner of collecting it, by enible Experiment (the urest of Guides) to convince thoe who oppugne, and reolve the Doubting, which he hath largely hewn. 3. Becaue the Anatomical Diquiition of the Pancreas, and its Juyce, is omitted by Sylvius, in the firt part of his Praxis, as not pertinent to his preent Scope, which omiion this Book upplies, and to which the aid Sylvius, in a manner, refers his Readers: So that he which deliberately reads this Book, will be thereby highly inducted to the ndertanding of the Doctrines and Notions of the mot Learned Sylvius, concerning the Pancreatick Juyce, throughout his whole Writings, as they relate to divere Dieaes, and Affections of the Body of Man.

The econd Commodity I hall propound is, That this Book doth mot Indubitably contain the certain Caues of all Agues, or Intermitting Feavers, with their true and effectual Rules of Curation. It is a wonder to ee the many Books which have been written concerning Agues, and Feavers, (perhaps as many as there are Old Womens Medicines for the cure thereof) and the great Diverity of Opinions concerning their
Caues and differences; o that, for a man exercied with a tedious Ague, to call a Councel of Phyitians to his Aitance, uually received no more Relief, than a Criminal Peron doth by the Verdict of a Jury, which delivers him from Prion, either to Death, or Banihment. Which hath formerly enrolled this Dieae in the Catalogue of thoe which were wont to be termed Opprobrium Medicorum, the Reproach of Phyitians.

Neither, in my Judgment, is it greatly to be wondered at, that Phyitians were wont to have no better ucces in the Cure of this Dieae, eeing they were involved in o many ncertainties about the Seat, and Caue thereof; ome aigning the Seat to be in the Blood in general, others in ome perticular Parts of the Veels, where the Blood happened to be tagnant; others in the Meeraick Veines; others in the Guts, and perticularly in the Colon, and everal other Conceits, as if they went about to gain the Knowledge of the true Seat, Arithmetically, by the rule of fale Poition. Then again, as to the Caues, and Reaons of Differences, whilt they acribed them to the Four Humours, viz. Blood, Choler, Phlegme, and Melancholy, and their different Degrees of Mition, and Putre-Faction, they ran upon uch Rocks as contantly hip-wracked the Barks of their Opinions: For, till, as they endeavoured to olve one difficulty that would arie, they caued the Rie of another. But this Author's Hypotheis,
being o free from all Intricacies, and Difficulties, renders it agreeable to Truth.

I have yet further to ay in the behalf of its Certainty, that is the Conequence of Curation; which, although every ingle Cure of a Dieae doth not indeed declare the Adminitrator of the Medicine, to have a certain Intelligence of the Caue of the Dieae; yet, when a Ditemper hall be certainly cured, at divers times, in different Perons, and with different Medicaments; alwayes from the Notions, Doctrines, and Coniderations of the ame Caue, that urely is a certain Argument that the Caue is known. And this I my elf have oft-times done even to Admiration, by removing Ague-Fits in a few dayes pace, and never yet failing of the Cure of any kind of Ague, whether Quotidian, Tertian, or Quartan, with their Compounds; and am yet (by God's bleing) ready, at any time, to undertake the cure of the wort Ague-Fits that are; which Aquiition, I acknowledge, I owe to this Author: I am able alo, to perform the ame in thoe deplorable Fits, commonly called, The Fits of the Mother.
I have intanced this not out of boating, but to hew the certainty, and excellency of the Doctrine of the Pancreatick Juyce, and to excite the Reader to a erious Contemplation, and Obervation thereof.

There is yet a Third tillity of this Book, which is, That it refutes everal Errours in Phyick, and Anatomy; many of which, in times pat, have been received for certain Truths, and ome of them perhaps yet remaining; the Principle whereof relate to the Pancreas, or Sweet-Bread, and to the Nervous Juyce; concerning which, I hall ay no more, but commit you to the things themelves, as they hall occur by reading.

I have nothing more to ay, but to beg the Readers kind Acceptance; and withall to mind him of the Difficulty of things of this Nature, (epecially when an Author writes in uch a tyle as de Graaf hath done) that if he meet with any Errours committed by me, I hope he will the more eaily pas them by, as not being Intentional, and I preume not Eentiall.
If I find this be kindly accepted, it will encourage me to erve my Country with ome-what of my own, more at large.

I do expect to be cenured, and narled at by ome (for as Eramus aith, Nihil moroius Hominum Judiciis) there is nothing more peevih than Mens Judgments, I hall eaily dipene with it, being of a peacable Spirit: And as I have profeed to do this for a Publick Good, o I alo declare, that I have been void
of Prejudice therein, to all Mens Perons, and Interets; being only deirous of the Propogagation of all Laudable Science, whilet I am

body.byline: Regnerus de Graaf, concerning the Pancreatick Juyce.

div.head: CHAP. I. A Decription of the Pancreas, before which ome things are put concerning the neceity of Anatomy, and its Increae.
div.p:
IT was never made a Quetion, (unles perhaps by uch through whoe ignorance True Phyick is digraced; or that cannot ditinguih the true Science of Phyick from the Emperical curing of Dieaes (that Anatomy is very ueful and neceary, as well for all
Phyitians as Chyrurgians; and that real Phyick without it's Knowledge cannot tand, or be in force; which is wont to be called Dogmatical and Rational.

Seeing it is o, their Ingenuity and Study deerves Praie, who endeavour to arrive to a greater degree of Perfection in the Knowledge of Anatomy, by making a narrow earch into the Secrets of Nature, and communicating thoe things which they have found out to others.

And amongt thoe who have given themelves up to this Work; neither frighted with it's difficulties, have had laudible ucces therein: Gapar Ae • ius the Anatomit, comes not far behind, who, when he had met with the Venae Lacteae, in the Year 1622. in a Dog which he undertook to open alive, he wholly gave himelf to the further Dicovery thereof; o that no Week paed without one or other Diection; not only of Dogs, but other living Creatures alo, as Cats, Lambs, Hogs, Cows, and alo Hores, as you may ee in that Book of his publihed after his Death. But dying young, he could not make a further progres in many other things, tending to this buines exactly to explain them, and communicate them to the Learned World: Concerning their ite and office, many Controveries, and Diputes have arien amongt Anatomits; for they who immagined that all the Chyle acended by the Meeraick Veins (in order to it's Sanguification by the Liver) did tiffly affirm, that thee Milky
Veels went to the Liver; but others decribed their coure another way.

And this matter remained in Doubt until the Year 1651. that the Ductus Thoracicus was found out by that mot ingenious Anatomit, John Pequet, a French-Man, to which it is evident to all men, the Veels dicovered by Aellius do tend, and there lay down the humour, or matter by them contained.

And that we may not only peak of trifles, we cannot pas by with ilence the famous Invention of the Bloods circulation by the incomparable William Harvey, chief Phyitian to the King of England, dicovered in the Year 1628. which although at the firt found many Oppoers, (to whom it eemed trange, that they being old, hould lay aide their old Doctrines, and be taught anew what younger men did mot certainly affirm) nevertheles, this Pillar of Truth remained unhaken againt the mot furious Aaults, and that o tedfatly, that not long after many Learned men were found, who conidering the olid ayings of the Ancients, after this new Invention was found out, that it might be explained after a far better, and eaier manner; plainly made it appear by the wrightings of Hyppocrates, that he undertood this circular Motion of the Blood, to whom they judge there were nothing in the Art of Phyick lay hid.

Yea, the matter is come o far, that you hall carcely find any Phyician of note, who doubts of the Bloods Circulation. So it requires
ome time to dipere the mits of mens contradicting any good, and new Inventions.

Many famous men both in Judgment and Practie, were tired up by the Examples of worthy and excellent Anatomits, by whoe Diligence about the ame time, viz. 1650. and 51. in divers Countries it was dicovered by Olaus Rudbechius, a Swede, and Thomas Bartholinus, a Dane, both famous in Anatomy; that the Lymphatick Veels were ditributed through the whole Body.

Alo the Ductus's were oberved in, or about the Year 1656. (by Thomas Wharton an Englih man) tending from the lower Maxillary Glandule by a traight paage to the Nipples; which are found alo at the flehly Ligature of the Tongue, near the Teeth: Through which eeing the Salival Humidity continually floweth to the Mouth for the moitning thereof, they are called Salivales, and alo Inferiores: To ditinguih them from the uperiour Salival Ducts, which running from the upper Maxillary Glandules, by a direct paage about the Cheek-Mucle to the former part of the Mouth by the region of the upper Eye-teeth, lay down their Spittle.

Which Invention we owe to Nicholas Stenonis a Dane, who dicovered them in the Year 1661. in his little Book for publick good. Alo by his Indutry were found out many other Veels paing into the Notrils and Mouth. We following his Example, ome years ince have oberved,
that the Glaudulous part of the Jaw being pret, a thick and vicous Humour came forth by the general opening of the Pores; from which time we thought that that vicous Matter which appears by Spitting, or other compreion of the Jaws, did in an epecial manner proceed from thoe Duct:

Jo. George Wirungus of Bavaria, is not ilently to be paed by (who can all to mind all Inventions) who was very excellent in the Study of Anatomy; in the Year 1642. at Padua, firt found out the Ductus Pancreaticus, which for the general good of Phyicians, he caued to be Engraven in Copper, from whom we might have expected more, had he not been wickedly Pitol'd by envious perons in his own Houe. Seeing therefore this famous man could not o ucceively find out the Ue of this Duct by his own Study, others, that they might be erviceable to the Phyical Republick, perited in the fame Labour, and with o much the more Earnetnes, in regard daily, there were more harp Diputes concerning it's true Office, and that epecially in the Univerity of Leyden in Holland; the mot famous and indeatigable Francicus de le Boe Sylvius leading the way; who when he had undertood the various Experiments which we had uccesfully made, by the diecting of divers Kinds of Animals, very often, as well in private as in publick, advied us, that we would commit to Writing thee things which we had oberved worthy of Note concerning this matter.

We ditruting our own Indutry, (and conidering that there are found ome (gluttons of Books, as they may be termed) who being timulated with the deire of Vain Glory, pare not to aault all with their cribling Pen, and currilous Language;) were almot afraid to enter upon this work.

Yet coniidering that for the publick good, any thing was to be born with a Couragious mind; we at lat put a helping hand to this Labour, and withal, have poliht our Endeavours, which o took with this worthy man, that he more urged their publication than before; as certain that we hould have the favour of all Learned Men, for doing a thing of o great moment to the Publick Good: and often aid, That we hould not fear to publih thee things which are clearly demontrated to our Eyes.

We being perwaded by the Council of him, and other learned men, thought it worthy our Labour, the decription of the Part being prefixt; afterwards the Judgments, and Opinions of others being explained, concerning this Juice, as we find it in every repect, to make it plain to all, and after to find out its true Ue.

The lower part of the Belly being opened, & the Intetines, with the Venticle removed, the Pancreas or Sweet-bread preently appears; concerning which, as we hall find occaion to peak more, in the following pages, we will pend a little time in the exact Delineation thereof

The Word Pancreas is Compounded of < in non-Latin alphabet >
and < in non-Latin alphabet > , as if they would ay that this vicous Part were all Fleh, which Apellation, notwithtanding is no way fit; but may be ued as Mony to pas from one to another Aellius and ome others of his Followers, particularly noting the middle-mot glandule of the Meentery, gave the firt Occaion of undertanding all its Parts, by one and the ame name.

The Subtanee of the Pancreas (or Sweet-Bread, if you except its Membranes and veels), is wholly Glandulous; made up of many mall Glandules; all which have o great a hardnes, and Strength, that being eparated from each other do till retain their proper form; and being put together, by reaon of their looe joyning, make a oft Body: o that, not without Reaon, they have called the Pancreas a looe and oft Glandule. Moreover, each Glandules, contituting the Pancreas, have their propper Membranes; and all being joyned together, are encompaed about with a Coat of ufficient Strength ariing from the Peritonaeum; by the benefit of which, they are trongly kept, with their little Veels, in their own place.

Its Scituation, in a man, is under the hindmot part, of the Ventricle, about the uppermot Vertebra of the Loynes, where it is firmly connected to the Peritonaeum. And it is extended from the Cavity of the Liver, viz. from the Entrance of the Venaporta, to the Region of the Spleen; by which means it is Tranverly Scituated, and not exactly in the middle of the Body; eing that the greatet part

thereof, is placed in the left Hypocondrium.
If you conider its Colour, it is pale, being altogether Glandulous; for the Blood gives little or no Colour to the Pancreas.

Its Figure is oblong, and broader, and thicker, towards the Intetinum Duodenum, and towards the Spleen narrower and thinner; nevertheles it is differently contituted in divere Animals; for in Dogs; Cats, Apes, Ottars, and others of the like Nature, it is Bipartite: So that one part acendeth towards the Stomach, and the other decendeth by the Membrane of the Meenterium, (according to the paage of the Intetine) to the which, it is on every ide firmly knit.
In Fihes and Fowls, for the mot part it is long and ingle.
The Magnitude of the Pancreas in Healthful bodies is mall, and compared with the other Bowels, comes hort of mot, yet in men of full growth, conidered with the other Glandules it exceeds them all.

It's Longitude is uually eight or ten Fingers breadth, which it eldom exceeds in men of perfect health. It's Latitude is ordinarily two Fingers broad, or two and a half. It's Thicknes, for as much as we could oberve in dead Bodies by us Diected, is a Fingers breadth. Finally, the weight is various, according to the divere Magnitude of the Animal in which it exits: We have with the mot curious VVharton, often oberved it in Men to be four or five Ounces, and in Hores about eleven. The Veels of the
Pancreas, by the mot accurate Searchers of Nature, are referred only to four Kinds, viz. Arteries, Veins, Nerves, and it's own proper Ductus. The Arteries borrow their Original from the Caeliaca, the Veins from the Ramus Splenicus; the Nerves from the ixth pair of Nerves, and the Ductus Pancreaticus eems to be derived from the Parenchyma of the Pancreas. For as much as each Glandules contituting the Pancreas, end forth mall Veels, which meeting in the middle thereof, make up this large Ductus.

This Veel which hath been before expoed to curious Eyes, in all appearance is Membranous; and although it be mall, nevertheles it is ufficiently trong. It's bignes near the Intetinum Duodenum, is about the quantity of a mall ized Quill, called a Pinion; but in it's progres towards the greater Lateral branches, and alo to the leer, running to all the Glandules of the Pancreas, it is divided, and gradually leened; wherefore by how much the more it approacheth the Spleen, by o much it is the les, and ends forth maller branches

This Ductus, or paage for the mot part, is wont in men to hew it's greatet branch in the lower part thereof, next to the Intetinum Duodenum, which hath more little branches than any other proceeding from the great Ductus, as appears by the following Table.

div.p: We think it to be worth our while to examine that in many and different Animals, which belongs to the Inertion of the Ductus Pancreaticus; eeing that Nature oftentimes in one is more depreed and obcure, in another, more clearly manifeted; o that none can truly determine concerning the Ue, and Office of any part, which hath not diligently examined the Fabrick, and Scituation, the Veels annexed, and other accidents in divers Animals.

For which Caue, we will briefly inert below the Differences, which we have oberved in everal kinds of living Creatures; as well that which belongs to the Ductus, as that which pertains to it's Inertion, that all may be able the better to judge of it's ue. There are ome Animals which have only one ingle Pancreatick Duct. Others there are which have it double, and latly, ome have three, when the Ductus is ingle; ometimes it enters with the Ductus Biliarius into the Intetinum Duodenum, and ometimes a part. When the Ductus is duplicate, ometimes one, ometimes both meet together with the Ductus Biliarius in the Intetine. But when the Ductus is threefold, ometimes one only, ometimes two, and ometimes
all three enter into the Intetine by the ame paage, and alo therein lay down a contained Humour. And if you conider the place of Inertion, it very much differs in divers living Creatures; for ome are found in which the Ducts do disburden themelves into the Intetines, and alo others in which they are dicharged into the Ventricle.

The ingle Ductus for the mot part is found in Man, Calves, Hogs, Hares, Conies, Cats, Dogs, Pikes, Carps, Eells, Barbils, &c. as we have formerly aerted; for in Men and Dogs we find it ometimes double, yet o as the econd is les than the former, viz. then that which paeth into the Duodenum with the Ductus Biliarius.

As often as thee two Ducts happen in the Animals but now cited, for the mot part they are conjoyned in the Pancreas; o that the one being blown up, the other will well; yet we find them o contituted in Man, that they are not joyned together, although both be extended to the extremity of the Pancreas almot in the ame Longitude and Magnitude. A twofold Ductus is commonly found in Pheaants, Peacocks, Geee, Ducks, and other Animals, epecially of the number of Fowls.

The threefold Ductus, for the mot part is in Cocks, Hens, Pigeons and Magpyes, &c. When the Ductus Pancreaticus is ingle, it is commonly joyned with the Ductus Biliarius about it's Inertion into the Intetinum, Duodenum, in Men and Fihes, as we have above declared;
as alo in Cats, in which once we found by the ide of the Gall-bladder, another little whitih Veel towards which the Pancreas in an extraordinary manner extending it elf, which being lightly compreed, there flowed a certain Matter into the Ductus Pancreaticus, like to the Juyce thereof, both in colour and ubtance: But the Bile in the ame Cat retained both it's natural ubtance and colour, o that nothing eem'd to be changed which related to it's natural Contitution.
The Ductus Pancreaticus, and the Ductus Biliarius are not joyned together, but enter the Intetine in divers places in Hogs, Calves, Conies, and Hares, &c.

When the Ductus Pancreaticus is twofold, or threefold, ometimes only one of them is joyned with the Ductus Biliarius, as is evident in Pyes, and ome other Birds, Sometimes two, as appears in Peacocks, Geee, Ducks, Pheaants; and Pigeons, in which now and then only one is joyned to the Ductus Biliarius: Sometimes all three being joyned therewith do pas into the Intetine, as we have ometimes oberved in Hens

Seeing we have already ufficiently poken of it's Inertion into the Intetine, it alo remains for us to peak omething concerning the place of Inertion, as more nearly appertaining to our buines. The Pancreatick Juyce doth immediately dicharge it elf into the Stomach in Barbils and Carps; but in other Creatures (for as much as we have oberved) it dichargeth
it elf into the Intetines, and that in divers places; for in Men it is performed about four Fingers breadth, under the Pylorus, and in Birds about eight Fingers breadth, but in Hares and Conies, the breadth of fifteen or ixteen Fingers below the Pylorus.

Here we would diligently note, that as often as we name the Ductus Biliarius, we always thereby undertand the Cyticus and Hepaticus; becaue thee two are always joyned together about the end, only in Pigeons excepted, which want the Gall-bladder, and furthermore, are aid to have no Gall; nevertheles, they have uually a threefold Ductus Biliarius, one of which enters immediately under the Pylorus, the other two make their entrance into the Intetine at a lower ditance. Where thoe Ducts enter the Intetines or the Ventricle, the inner Tunicle of that part buncheth out, being wrinckled like a Navel; for which caue it more difficultly admits the Stile then the Ductus Biliarius, which is broader and not o lax.

There is no value found throughout the Ductus Pancreaticus, nor in it's Inertion to the Ductus Biliarius, as is rahly and fally affirmed by ome. And thee few Obervations may be ufficient as concerning the Syteme of the Pancreas; and no man ought to think, who hath oberved o great a variety in it, and o many notable ports of Nature about it, that the Pancreas is lightly made; for the Liver, the Spleen, and everal other Entrails of Animals,
alo highly neceary, being different in themelves are found out by uch, who diligently apply themelves to the Diecting of undry living Creatures; neither will they eaily ay it is unprofitable, who have oberved it to be found in all kinds of Animals.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Opinions of undry Authors concerning the Office and Ue of the Pancreas examined.
div.p:
AS concerning the ue of the Pancreas, it was not o much accounted of in former dayes as now it is; for Hyppocrates, the reverend light and deity of ome Phyicians gave the Pancreas no Name, concerning which now a dayes, o many Opinions are een in Authors: For ome think it only to erve as a Pillow placed underneath the Ventricle, or Stomach, and for the ditribution of the Veels. Others that it received the Chyle from the Intetines: Others imagined that it purged the Excrement of the Chyle: Others that it were as the Bilarveicle of the Spleen: Others, that the thicker and more unapt purgations of the Blood, were purged into it by the ordinary coure of Nature: Others, that this part was made for the Reception of the Excrement of the Nerves.
Finally, others have publickly taught, that the Humour in the Pancreas was not only ueful, but highly neceary to be undertood.

The firt Opinion may be acribed to the Ancients, that this part is as a pillow under the Stomach, and erveth to ditribute the Veins and Arteries; as Vealius, the mot ingenious Anatomit of his time ufficiently affirmes, who broke forth into thee words about the Fabrick of Mans body, Lib. 5. cap. 4. De omento. This body in Man (peaking of the Pancreas) is more white than red, every where attended by the branches of the Vena porta, Arteries and Nerves, that their Complications may be the more firm, being only upported by the lower Membrane of the Omentum; that it may be placed under the Stomach like a prop, or pillow.

But this Opinion is no way probable; eeing then the Pancreas in Birds, Fihes, and many other living Creatures, in which it is otherwie cituate then in Men would be ueles; becaue in thoe it is in no wie found to be o placed under the Ventricle, neither doth it admit a paage to the Veels, unles in a very few. But becaue the Ancients never had a true knowledge of the Glandules, we mut not blame them for not delivering to us the true Ue of the Pancreas.

The econd Opinion is attributed to Baccius and Folius, both which harply maintained, that the Chylus paeth from the Intetines to the Liver and Spleen, through the Ductus Pancreaticus:
The contrary of which is as clear as the Meridian Sun: Seeing that nothing is received from the Gutts into this Ductus, but only the Juyce ent forth by it elf to the Intetines.

The third Opinion is acribed to Johan. Velingius; becaue in his Syteme of Anatomy, chap. 4. he thus peaketh of the Pancreas: The ue of this Ductus is not obcure, for eeing it hath acertain Juyce not much unlike to the Bile, it is manifet that uch an Excrement is eparated from the Chylus by a further Concoction, and being conveyed into this Veel, is thence emitted into the Duodenum. Aellius, Riolanus and others favour this Opinion; but Experience contradicts it, and manifetly heweth, that the Humour contained in the Pancreas is never really in it elf bitter, and therefore in no wie to be compared with the Bile.

If at any time it happens that the Probe being put into this Ductus be yellow, every one will eaily believe, that this is not occaioned by the Humour contained in the Pancreas, but from the Bile, as well flowing from the Ductus Cyticus, as the Hepaticus immediately into the Intetine; epecially if he conider that the Stylus is potted by the Bile, before it paeth from the Intetine to the Ductus Pancreaticus; and again, that it paeth through the Bile whilt it is drawn out: For the Ductus Pancreaticus, and the Ductus Biliarius in Men perforate the Intetine in the ame place.

And although the mot famous D. Van. Horne, in a Bilious Diarhaea aw that Veel full of Choler, we ay it was Preternatural, in as much as the Bile, which Copiouly adhered to the end of the Ductus (as is wont to happen in a Diarhaea) was thrown into the Cavity thereof, by the Agitation of that dead Body: Alo that the excrement of the further Elaboration or Concoction of the Chylus, is not ent into this paage, is manifet, in regard the ame is witneed by Occular Inpection. In ome Animals, that Glandulous Body doth not at all touch the Milky Veels; and in others it only paeth over, and in no wie enters their Subtance; as alo becaue they are eaily eparated from the Pancreas, without the Effuion of any Chyle, as we have formerly demontrated in Dogs, Cats, and other Animals.

Therefore we do not ee upon what ground they might maintain the further Concoction of the Chylus to be celebrated in it, unles they following the Opinion of Aellius, would take this Glandulous body for the Middle Glandule of the Mefentery, into which the Venae Lacteae are altogether immered. The fourth Opinion is of Bartholinus, as is manifetly apparent from his Anatomy Chap. 13. De Pancreate; where he thinks the Bile to be purged Naturally by its Ductus, and will have it to be the Bilar-Veicle or Gall-Bladder of the Spleen; o that the ame ue which the other affords to the Liver, he believes that this affords to the Spleen: Which Opinion (by the
leave of o great a man) Anatomy in our Judgment eems to confute: Seeing the Ductus Pancreaticus paeth not to the Spleen; neither are there any other Veels, which do convey any thing from the Spleen to it: For, there are found only two kinds of Veels, which carry any thing back from the Spleen, viz. The Veines and Lymphatick Veels: But the Veines carry back the Blood to the Liver, and the Complication of the Lymphaticks carrying from the Spleen, do not in like manner go to the Pancreas, but to the great Receptacle of the Chyle; o that nothing can be dicharged out of the Spleen to the Pancreas, as our tryal in France hath ufficiently manifeted, for their akes, who judging this to be the bet Opinion of mot Authors, rejected ours. We tyed a Dog upon a Table, as is Demontrated by the firt Figure of the third Table; and when we had made a little Hole in the left Hypocondrium, with our two fore-Fingers we pull'd out the Spleen, whoe Bloody Veels we tyed with two or three everal Ligatures, and afterwards we cut the ame in under between the Spleen and the Bonds; and when we had quite taken away the Spleen, we drew together the Lips of the Wound with mall threds in three or four everal places, whereby this Dog, in ahort time, being well cured, was returned to us, (at which we did not at all wonder, becaue we once had a Bitch, which brought forth three or four Puppies after the Extirpation of her Spleen); and two
Mouths after the los of the Spleen in the ame Dog, we collected a notable quantity of the Pancreatick Juice, which the Profeors of Andegave, the Doctors of trecht, D. Haverloo, and D. de Maets, judged to be acidly Salt: which being true, none as we think free from Prejudice, will maintain that the Succus Pancreaticus proceeds from the Spleen.

Alo, it is worthy to be noted, That thoe Dogs did no les greedily deire, or better diget, their Food after the Extirpation of the Spleen, than before; from whence we, receding from the Common Opinion, judge that no Fermentitious Matter or Humour is ent from the Spleen to the Stomach.

The Fifth Opinion is attributed to the mot Famous Lindanus, eeing that in his Medic-Phyiol. c. 5. Art. 5. pag. 114. he aith, When I conider what appertains to the e, beides the tructure of the Pancreas; how many Dieaes Practie takes notiee of in it, I cannot doubt but that the thicker, and more ueles Purgations of the Blood, are thrown out into it, by the Ordinary Law of Nature; o as they may be corrected by the Spleen: and alo by an Extraordinary: all the Melancholy which either an Intemperate Diet, or Dieae hath bred. The Ductus it elf gives us caue to believe, That they are both carryed to the Intestines; and Curation teacheth the ame by the Medicines often required. And this Opinion eems alo to us to be contrary to the Truth, eeing that the Pancreatick Juice, as often as it hath been truly collected by us, alwayes appeared Limpid like Wine.

But what we hall ay concerning the Excrementitious Humour, will ufficiently appear by the following Article, and alo by thoe things which hall be poken of preently after. The Sixth Opinion is manifet enough from Wharton's Treatie of the Glandules, Chap. XIII. whilt he writes. Therefore I think that this Glandule (as likewie all others) do miniter to the Nerves, and that it receives ome of the Superfluities of the Nerves, of the Sixth Paire, with the little Branches of the Spinal Marrow, in the greater folding of the nitings; and by its own Proper Veel carries it to the Intetines.

But eeing that the Nerves are deigned to carry Animal Spirits, we do not undertand upon what ground the indutrious Anatomit will hold, that the Excrementitious humour is carryed through them, and wherefore he will affirm that it is rather carryed into the Pancreas than into the Spleen, or other parts of the Body, to which Nerves of the ame Original do belong.

Truly the Pancreas is too far from the Brain to receive its Excrement; moreover, the Nerves abhor all acrimony, o as to receive any harper Juice: For which caue, we judge this Opinion to tand upon too light a Foundation to be admitted for Truth; and o much the les, eeing we could never perceive any Cavity or Liquour in the Nerves, notwithtanding all the diligence we could ue to this purpoe, the mot accurate Microcopes have been of no ue to us, for the dicovery of the
leat pores in them: We do not here peak of the ditances which are like Pores, een between the mall Conveyances of the Nerves; but of the Cavity it elf, of the little Pipes, by which thee Excrements ought to pas. Furthermore, it is proved by Ligatures that no remarkable quantity of Humour is carryed by the Nerves, in which there is not the leat Swelling, of either ide the Ligature which we have obererved, nor yet by any other that we read of.

That which Chyrurgions cry out of the dropping of the Nerves, we rather acribe to the hurt of the Lymphatick Veels, being nigh to the Nerves, than the hurt of the Nerves themelves; for which reaon, that we might have a more certain information, we have ometimes in Dogs, laid bare that notable Nerve in the hinder-mot part of the Legs, and cut it cros through the middle, and have put it into a Vial, being freed from the Lymphatick Veels (as we ue to do in collecting of the Pancreatick Juice), the neck of which was o traightned for this purpoe, as that the Nerves being cut aunder, the Orifice might be well cloed by its thicknes, that Spirits, or whatoever ubtile Matter paeth through the Nerves, might not vanih into the Aire. We fixed this Vial to the skin with the Nerve hanging down into its Hollownes, hoping that if any Liquor did pas through the Nerves, we hould by that means attain it, but in vain: For, in the pace of four or five hours, we got
not the leat drop; nor did we oberve that the Animal Spirits did adhere by Condenation to the ides of the Glas.

Such Birds are to be catcht with more ubtile nets; which after they are taken, we will prepare to break-fat withal. Seeing therefore little or no viible matter is carried through the Nerves, we pray the Propugners of this Opinion to tell us, Why Nature in the Pancreas (as they will have it) hath only formed a Ductus to receive the Excrements of the Nerves, which ometimes exceed in Magnitude the Recurrent Nerves themelves, whoe mall Branches often touch the Pancreas. What appertains to the word Excrement, whereby they point out our Juice, we think it not convenient for it, if they undertand whatoever is eparated from the Blood, whether good or evil; but it is in no repect agreeable to the Pancreatick Juice, if by the word Excrement they undertand whatoever is carryed from the Blood to be unprofitable, for Reaons hereafter to be declared.

The Seventh Opinion is aigned to the mot Famous Francicus de la Boe-ylvius; who thinks nothing is carryed from the Intetines to the Pancreas, by this Ductus; nor any ecret unprofitable Excrement by the ame to the Intetines; but a commendable Humour prepared therein of Blood, and Animal Spirits; and o conveyed to the Intetine, and permixed with the Alement.

And in regard he knew that nothing was carryed to the Intetines, but what was firt wallowed into the Stomach, and by that driven out again through the Pilorus, or is ent through the Bilar, or Pancreatick Ductus; and he moreover conidering, not only in intermitting Feavours, that the ick were alwayes troubled with various pains in their Loynes, by Cold, Heat, Yawnings, Reachings, and Vomitings, as well of inipid Phlegm, and ometimes acid, as of Choler; ometimes bitter, ometimes acid and bitter, &c. but alo in other dieaes proceeding from hence to the Hypocondriack Affection. As for example, in the Scurvey, the Dieae called the Suffocation of the Womb, the Chollerico Paio, pains of the Belly, and conequently from hence in the Ulcerated Mouths, or Thruhes of Children, &c. Belchings, and Acid Humours do arie, he concluded (although he never aw the Pancreatick Juice, as he ingenuouly confeeth, The. 37. of the ue of the Spleen and Glandules) that the Pancreatick Juice, in its own Nature was Subacid, in an epecial manner tempered by the animal Spirits.

For, he judged that the Bile which is bitter and contrary to Acidity, could not be the caue of an acid Humour; and therefore he determines that Spittle, alwayes inipid in ound men; and oftentimes o acid, and remarkably harp in the ick, came not from the Pancreatick Juice.

And becaue we heard that mot Learned man often teaching thee and the like things, and did ee the ame confirm'd by a happy practie in the Hopital; his opinion o pleaed us, that we never frequented his Meetings, whether publick or private, without great atifaction of mind; in which, being excited to find out the further truth of the matter, by the ame worthy peron and his Diciples, we have undertook the work; and although we could not once depair of a happy ucces; in proces of time, God favouring our Enterprize and Deires, in the Year 1662. found out the way of Collecting the Pancreatick Juice; which, by way of Hitory, as it hall conveniently occur in the Work, we will et down: In which our Thoughts hipwrackt themelves from thoe cruples, by which they may be precautioned, who will follow our foot-teps to examine it.

div.head: CHAP. III. In what manner the Pancreatick Juice was found out.
div.p: THE Firt Experiment by which we undertook to collect the Pancreatick Juice in a living Dog, was a Ligature with which we tied the upper-part of the Pancreas, together with the thin Gut; for, by that means, we hoped that after ome Hours we hould have found the Pancreatick Duct well'd with Juice, but in vain: which eemed to our Judgment to happen by reaon that the Motion of the Blood being hindered to the Pancreas, the eparation of the Juice from it was prevented alo.

The Second Experiment was alo by a Ligature made about the Inertion of the Ductus into the Intetinum Duodenum, but alo in vain. The Reaon perhaps was the Glandules of the Pancreas being hurt, by whoe Ductus all the Pancreatick Juice might the more eailier have flown out, by reaon that neither in the great Ductus nor in the lateral branches is there any values found.

The Third Experiment was by two boards or planks, higher in the middle, than at the ends, applyed and traightly bound to the Duodenum,
at the ingres of the Pancreatick Ductus; from whence, after ome hours, the Abdomen being opened again, which before had been lightly titched up, we found the Pancreatick Ductus welled with a clear and limpid Juice; nevertheles, we could not conveniently either take it out, or tat it. By which ucces we being animated the more, reolved a fourth Tryal, by opening the Intetinum Duodenum, according to the Longitude thereof; and preently applying a little veel to the Orifice of the Ductus Pancreaticus, as the firt Figure of the following Table A. demontrates; afterwards by traightly tying the aid Intetine about the neck of the veel: o that its Orifice was diametrically oppoite to the end of the Ductus Pancreaticus, not doubting but by this means we hould gather a rare quantity of the Pancreatick Juice; but this alo in vain: without doubt, becaue the air included within the veel, denyed entrance to the Pancreatick Juice, lightly touching it. Therefore we reolved to try a Fifth Experiment, with a little veel mally perforated, as the firt Figure of the Second Table hews under the letter B. By which advantage, in the pace of five hours, we collected o great a quantity of Liquor, that the veel was almot half full; whoe contained Liquor was of a bitter relih, and of a yellowih colour; which we judged to happen, becaue the bile, (by reaon the Intetine was not firt cleaned) was intermixed with the Succus Pancreaticus. Wherefore, after many
and tireome vexations of mind, we came to a Sixth Experiment; which eeing it in all repects ufficiently anwered our Expectations; here wee will add its exact decription for the ake of the Curious, that they may give credit to their proper enes, which in others words mot eaily leen the Credit.

A little Veel, with a longer neck, was taken, as the II. Table under the letter A. repreents; in the upper part of whoe Belly a little hole was pierced B.; by which the air included in it, gave way to the Pancreatick Juice.

Let the neck of the Veel be encompaed with a little cord C.; and everall Rings of Iron, thereunto affixed, or any other convenient thing; by the advantage of which, the Intetine may the more eaily be tretched up.

Furthermore, you mut take a wild Ducks quill D. becaue that kind of bird hath longer and thinner than all others, which mut be o obvolved about the larger part thereof with Paper, a little bemeared with boiled Starch, that the Orifice of the veel H. whilt it is included in it, may be mot exactly cloed: let either the Bile or Blood, penetrating by the ides of the quill, defile the Juice collected, or to be collected in the Veel.

This quill is affixed to the Veel, by reaon of the traightnes of the Pancreatick Duct, which will not admit the neck of the Veel. Preently you mut take a little tap or topple
made of oft Wood, and of uch thicknes that it may fill up the narrower Orifice G. which with the Alligated thred K. by the help of the Style may be o far protruded through the larger part of the quill F. that a little thereof may remain in the larger part of the quill G. and there may tick o fat, that it may not return of its own accord into the Ductus Pancreaticus: becaue then the Pituitous or Vermiculous cruted matter, of the Intetines, continually adhering about the end of the Ductus being moved, would eaily caue it to be obtructed; which need not be feared, if the topple remain in the quill.
But the Tap is not o trongly to be forced into the Quill, but that by the help of the thred it may eaily be retracted. You have all thee things et forth in the Second Figure of the Second Table.

div.p: All the Intruments aforeaid being prepared and fitted, a Dog to is be taken; to whom, for the pace of ome hours, no food hath been given: But, a young Mative is to be preferred; becaue he, of all other Dogs, of the ame Magnitude, hath larger Bowels, and by reaon of the Humidity predominating in him, yeildeth more Pancreatick Juice, and alo longer Life, and moreover les trouble in diffecting. We ay that a fating Dog is to be taken, let that the Intetines, with the Ventricle waxing bigger by aliment, the Cloure of the Abdomen, after the Application of the Glas, be impedited; or alo, the mouth of the Quill, by the two much Compreion of the Bowels, be hut up.

Having got uch a Dog, after his Mouth in trictly bound that he may not bite; and having tyed his extended Legs, upon a Table, let the Style be thrut under the Larynx, the long Mucles being firt removed, bending his neck; which done, let there be made a little hole in that part thereof, which is mot prominent, by cutting the Particles of the two Cartilages; that by the ame Hole, his troubleome cry, to the tanders by, being removed, a Repiration be procured. In uch ort as is hewed, Tab. III. Fig. I. Thee things premized, you mut open the Abdomen with one inciion, according to the White line from the word-like Cartilage, unto the Region of the Pubes; then preently draw the Gut through the Wound, and make a Ligature about it three or four fingers breadth below the Pylorus, as alo under the end of the Ductus Pancreaticus, let the Aliments liding from the Ventricle, or thoe things contained in the Guts, by their Peritaltick Motion, againt things thrut forward, hould diturb or hinder this our VVork.

Then between both Ligatures, let the Intetine be cut open in its Anteriour Part, being firt freed from the Meentery; by and by the Bile, with the Phleme, and other matter found therein, being cleaned away by a Sponge, the Ductus Pancreaticus may be oberved; the which, with almot two Fingers breadth beneath the end of the Ductus Biliarius, and well nigh the ame pace above the Connexion of
the Intetine, with the decending part of the Pancreas, into Ductus of the narrower Orifice is gently to be immitted, the end of the Quill hut up with its Spout or topper, with the Glas veel on the other part fatned to it; which, by the mediation of the little Cord, containing the Rings C. it is ewed to the Intetine with a double thred; o that, the extremity of the quill G. may remain in the Ductus Pancreaticus; nor the Veel recede from the Intetine. VVhich things rightly performed, the Abdomen is to be ewed together with a thick thred, that the Veel may hang forth without the Cavity thereof, as is to be een Fig. II. Tab. III. To which, now part of an Exiccated Bladder N. is to be o bound with a tring about the neck of the Veel, that it may on every ide cover the Veel; let the blood or bile flowing by the hole of the Veel B. might enter into it. Thee things o done, the Tap or Stopple I. by the help of the thred K. is to be drawn through the hole B. This Intrument will alwayes be ufficient where the Ductus Pancreaticus hath only one paage into the Intetine; but if beides this ordinary Ductus, there be yet another paage, as in like manner we have ometimes found; there is another Intrument required, by which that alo may be cloed. The which Intrument in the end we thought upon, as being more agreeable to this matter, then that of which we have already dicoured in the third Experiment, and it is noted, Tab. II. Fig. III.

It hath two Tables made of Ivory AA In the extremity of which are four holes BBBB. Thee Tables may be o applyed between the Ventricle and the Veel, affixed to both ides of the Intetine; and the intermediate Intetine may be omewhat compreed with the hand, till the acute Style, and the Clynders CC. be tranmitted through the holes, and through the Scrues DD.

The intermediate Intetine may be o traightned, that nothing from thee Secondary Ducts (which we have alwayes found to be preent in the Superiour place) may flow out; by which means all the Juice flowing through that Ductus, in which the Quill is immitted may be received by the affixed Veell.

div.head: CHAP. IV. In which the Qualities of the Pancreatick Juice are decribed: By a plain Diviion of the Glandules of the whole Body, is hown that the Succus Pancreaticus is not Excrementitious: Alo, How it is Generated.
div.p: HAving related the Intruments with their manner of applying, there is none but may ee that we may eaily come to a more intimate knowledge of the Pancreatick Juice, by oberving not only the qualities thereof, but alo the Quantity which at all hours do flow to the Intetinum Duodenum.
The Qualities of the Pancreatick Juice o collected, both Viible and Tactable, uch as we have frequently oberved them, we hall here et down for the ake of thoe who deire to be informed.

As often as we have rightly collected the Pancreatick Juice, we have found it like clear Fountain Water, with ome-thing of Vicidity, but not without the aociating of Diipated Spirits. The Qualities thereof are perceptible to the tat; not alwayes in the ame manner in themelves, which denote thoe Functions depending upon it, not eldome to be vitiated, and the ame is evinced by our Experience; For, we ometimes have found it mot gratefully acid, ometimes almot inipid, ometimes autere, often times alt, but mot often acidly alt.

Of this our Experience, we cite an approved Witnes, the mot excellent D. Vander Sprongh, with the mot famous Profeor Sylvius, as alo many others who have ometimes been Fellowes of our practical Colledge, who in their preence judged with us, that in uch a Collection it were both of an autere, and acidly Salt Sapor.

The notable Effect of the Auterity thereof, then alo oberved, we will hereafter declare. Now having found out the Pancreatick Juice, that we may clearly and ditinctly ubject the Generation thereof to your Eyes, we will propoe a decription of all the Glandules, by ditinguihing them with the Famous D. Sylvius into Conglobated and Conglomerated. We call them conglobated, which are Contituted, as it were, from one continued Subtance, having an equal Superifices; uch as in the Meentery, Neck, Shares, and other parts of the Body, many are found.

But we call thoe Conglomerated, which rie from many leer Glandules joyn'd together; uch are the Pancreas, Salival Ducts, and many others in the Fauces, Notrils; yea they contitute the Thyme it elf, or Glandule, under the Channel bone, concerning which we are willing here to ay omewhat of what we have ome years ince oberved, whilt we were Converant about the diecting of Calves (in which this Glandule was found very great, and that which is mot worthy of note, no les in Calves, than in other Animals, That it is enibly diminihed after the Birth) that this notable Ductus was found repleat with a Limpid humor, which we ometime proecuted; but becaue, upon the laying open thereof, the Liquor did continually Flow out, the intire Ductus vanihed away before we could enter its end: For which reaon, we were contrained to defer its further Enquiry till another occaion.

That this Ditinction of the Glandules is not Fained but Real, the following Experiment doth prove. As well the Conglomerated as the Conglobated are cloathed with a Coat or Membrane; which being taken away, and a certain Liquor immitted, as well through the Ductus Pancreaticus, as through the Salivales; alo by the Arteries of all the Glandules, by the help of a Syringe with divers little pipes fatned to the ame, contrived by us, and propoed in our Treatie concerning the Organs of men; as ubervient to many
things in Generation; and there will be oberved by a mot Elegant Spectacle Conglomerated Glandules, receding or parting by coure from themelves; epecially if from hence the little Membranes, whereby they are connexed, be cut with a Knife: Which, in no wie, is to be expected from the Conglobated Glandules, notwithtanding the greatet diligence.

Beides the Glandules differ among themelves, in relation to their Subtance: Becaue in the ordinary coure of Nature, we have found a Cavity in the middle of the Conglobated Glandules; but not in the Conglomerated; which, by that great Expounder of Nature, and by an indioluble bond of Friendhip endeared to us, Nicholas Stenon, we have een noted; and oberved; who in his Anatomical Obervations concerning the Conglobated Glandules, aith:
div.q: For, outwardly the Conglobated Glandules are hollow not inwardly like a Baon, yet if you rightly enter the Separation between the protuberating Lips on every ide, you hall find as it were a Cleft or Chap, by which go forth certain Lymphatick Roots returning with the Membrane.
div.p:
Their Subtances differ not only among themelves by way of Connexion, as they are Conglobated and Conglomerated, but alo in the peculiar Veels; for, the Conglobated are given to the Lymphatick Veels, which towards, and at the Common Ductus Thoracicus, or the Superior Folding thereof, epecially
Conpicuous in Dogs, drive out a Liquor prepared in themelves, or received from another. But the Conglomerated dipoe their Liquour into peculiar Cavities, as the Salivales into the Mouth, the Pancreas into the Duodenum, and o of others.

That the Motion of the Lympha is uch, as we have even now aerted, and not from the Centre to the Circumference, is proved by the Values in the Lymphatick Veels, every-where exiting, as may be een in a little Treatie, concerning the Values of the Lymphatick Veels, by the mot Famous, and our entire Friend, Dr. Raych, Anatomyt of Amterdam, Printed Anno 1665. by whoe Indefatigable Dilligence, at the ame time, was dicovered that Veel which he calleth the Bronchial Artery, by reaon that it accompanyeth the Widenings of the Branches of the harp Artery through the whole Subtance of the Lungs; as may be een by the Figure thereof, inerted into his little Book, aforementioned, and worthily Communicated to us.

Seeing that the Duct's, and alo the Subtances of the Glandules are divere, it is worthy our enquiry, Whether the Humour, oberved in all the Glandules, be of the ame, or a different Quality? But we hall anwer, That the ame, or like Humour is eparated in all the Glandules, of a divere Species; for one Liquor is depoed in the Conglobated, and another in the Conglomerated: For, that which is eparated in the Conglobated is all of the ame
Nature: which is proved, not only by the Subtance of the ame Glandules, every where Conimilar, but alo by the wayes by which they are all ditburdened; for as much, as further appears to us, ending in the Ductus Thoracicus. Moreover, it is further Demontrable, by the Liquor of the Conglobated Glandules, ordinarily found more Saltih, and les Acid in them, than in the Conglomerated Glandules of the Pancreas; nevertheles more of Acidity, and Salitude, than that of the Conglomerated Salivales. From whence it is manifet, that a Liquor is eparated from the Conglomerated Glandules of the Salivales, and Pancreas not alike in all its Qualities, as we have aerted even now to be done in the Conglobated; in which matter, that we might be more certain, at the ame time, and to the ame Animal, we applyed the Intrument depicted Tab. II. Fig. II. both to the Ductus Pancreaticus, and to the upper Salivary Duct, as is exhibited Tab. III. Fig. II. But we found a notable diverity of the aforeaid Liquors; For, the Salival is either Temperate or Inipid; but the Succus Pancreaticus is acidly Salt, or uch like, for the mot part, as we have decribed it in the former Chapter.

Seeing there is a divere Juice of divere Glandules, it deerves our enquiry, What ue every one may have, and whether it be proitable or unneceary? That is, Whether it bringeth any Commodity to the Body? Or, Whether it be uch as is in no wie Subervient
to the Oeconomy of the Humane Fabrick? It will not be hard to atisfie this difficulty, epecially if we make a more exact Scrutiny into the Motion of thoe Liquors; for eeing that all the Liquor of the Conglobated Glandules, is inerted into the Ductus Thoracicus, and there permixed with the Chyle, the chief part of Aliments, and with the ame may proceed, and be purged into the Jugular Veine, or left Subclavian Veel; from whence, being confued with the decending Blood, necearily paeth through the right Ear of the Heart, into its right Ventricle. We do not ee by what name it may be called Excrementitious and unprofitable; becaue the Excrementitious Humours are eparated from the Blood: o that, according to the Order of Nature, they may not any more be commixed therewith; but are wholly eparated from the Body; which is clearly een in the Urine; the which, being eparated from the mae of Blood in the Reines, and thence deduced through the Ureters into the Bladder: from whence, after ome tay, according to the Dictate of the Will, by the Urinary paage it is excluded from the Body; o that it can never again return.

So, the Juice of the Conglomerated Glandules, is effued through particular Ducts, into divers Cavities of the Body, where it may be mingled with other Humours neceary for Nourihment, and is leat of all to be eteemed for Excrementitious, or Unprofitable. Which that it may likewie, be made known, in like
manner, as we have proecuted the Liquor of the Conglobated Glandules; o alo, we hall follow that of the Conglomerated flowing from the Salivales, and the Pancreas.

The Spittle is eparated from the Blood, in the Maxillary Glandules, as well the Superiour as the Inferiour, and is carryed by the aid Salival Ducts, into the Cavity of the Mouth; where it may be mixed with the aumed Aliment, or out of the time of the Aliments Aumption, is continually wallowed; the which we never better conider, than whilt we hold omthing in our Mouth; the which, becaue of the cleannes of the place, in which we are, we will not pit out, neither dare we wallow it down; for the Mouth is very quickly fill'd with Spittle.

Therefore the Spittle, although without our knowledge, is continually wallowed, and mingled, and confued in the tomack with the Aliment, which truly would be very indecent, if the ame were unprofitable and excrementitious.

The Pancreatick Juice is e •• ued in the glandules of the pancreas, after the ame manner as the Spittle in the alivales, being continually eparated in a Man about the breadth of four fingers under the Pylorus into the intetinum duodenum, and there is mixed with the Aliments already paed the fermentation of the tomack, and with the ame is driven downwards by the peritaltick motion of the Gutts; in which propulion the greatet part thereof, together with the more pure and
liquid part of the Aliment is carried to the venae Lacteae, and thence to the Citern; from thence it penetrates through the Ductus Thoracicus to the ubclavian Vein, and o forward to the right Ventricle of the Heart; which indeed would happen againt reaon, if the aid humours were Excrementitious, and unprofitable to the oeconomy of the body of Man.

To this Opinion, beides Sylvius, agrees Godofridus Moebius, who in his Phyiological foundations of Medicine, c. 12. concerning the ue of the Intetines, thus peaketh: But this Juice (namely the Pancreatick) eeing that it may be admixed with the Chyle, together with the Bile in the Duodenum, without all doubt it further helps and promotes its Fermentation: For, if the pure purged Excrement hould be of no ue, Nature would have derived that Channel to the lower Intetines, wherein hard and unprofitable Excrements are lodged, not to the Superiour, where the Chyle begun in the Stomach, ought to be perfected.

Seeing than that by Reaons and Experiments, already ufficiently inferd, it is manifet, That the Humours, as well of the Conglobated, as the Conglomerated Glandules, are not Excrementitious. We think fit, before we proceed any further, to propoe their Way or Mode of Generation.

It hath been, in times pat, believed by the Antients, (to ay nothing concerning Faulties, and other their Figments) that the Glandules
did imbile Superfluous Humidities, like unto Sponges. But to the Neotericks, it eemed after a more attentive Examination of their Structure, that this Simillitude was greatly wide of the Truth; by reaon the Glandules are not every where open to the Pores, but are ufficiently cloathed on all ides with a trong Membrane; & therefore they think that nothing entreth into the Glandules, unles it be thither propelled by the Arteries and Nerves.

But the Arteries carry the Humours of every kind to the Glandules, under the Colour of Blood; every of which, by reaon of a certain Dipoition of the Pores, even as Seives do admit uch Particles of the Humours, which in repect of their Magnitude, and Figure, have the greatet Analogy, with the little Pores; in the mean while excluding others, which have with them a leer Simillitude; which therefore by the name of Blood, are contrained to return to the Heart; from whence, being more exalted in their paage, they are preently driven indicriminately, by the Pulifick force thereof, to the Glandules, and other parts of the Body; but, notwithtanding the Particles fitted to the Generation of the Pancreatick Juice, are no where more eaily eparated than in the Pancreas, no where more erous than in the Reins, no where more commodiouly Bilious than in the Liver; & o of the ret: Becaue there are ome parts of the Body which do more commodiouly receive this or that Humour into the Pores than others.

Nature hath therefore invented a ingular Artifice, whereby it doth o happily abolve o divere a work, in divere parts of Animals; which they do les admire, who diligently conider with themelves, that the like thing doth necearily happen in Plants: For, we ee various Plants, poited in the ame Sand, each to admit a peculiar Juice; which, nevertheles, is o Homo-geneous, that it may contain in it elf divere Particles, as we ee in Trees, whereon, by the Indutry of Gardeners, divers Fruits do grow; whereas alo divers Branches or Twigs are grafted into the ame Stock; which by reaon of the different Contitution of their Pores, they admit this, and not that part of the Liquor or Sap, others being excluded, which have a leer Affinity with their Pores.

The which things being equally granted, we may inferre, that the matter fitted to the generation of the Pancreatick Juice, is eparated from the Blood by a certain dipoition of the Pancreas; yet not o exactly, but that it may bring divers other Particles with it; as occular Inpection doth acertain us to happen in the Reins; in which indeed primarily the more Serous Particles of the blood, after the manner of Trancolation, are eparated from its intire Mae; yet, nevertheles, we note thoe many Saline, Bilious, and other Humours; which are, as it were, natcht away therewith, by reaon of them or thoe Particles largely abounding in the Body; in like manner as Chymitry
doth Demontrate all thee things to our Eyes, as clear as the Meridian Light.

The Animal Spirits joyne themelves to the Succus Pancreaticus by a continual Circulation, continually eparated from the Blood, with which, being joyn'd together by an Amicable Connexion, they run into the Intetinum Duodenum. From whence it is Conpicuous, that our Pancreatick Juice is not imple, but compounded of divers; this epecially, Acid, Aqueous, Saline, and other Particles therein found, adjoyned to the Animal Spirits; by whoe Volatile Sweetnee the force of Acids is retrained; whence it happens, that the Pancreatick Juice is Naturally Acidly-Temperate.

Some may ay, after what manner may the Pancreatick Juice be Acidly Temperate, eeing that in the Precedent Chapter we have aid, that it is very often Acidly-alt, and naturally may be aid to be uch as alwayes, or for the mot part, it happeneth to be? But, we hall Anwer, That perhaps it o happeneth in Dogs onely; becaue they ought to diget Bones, and other things of a harder Concoction, but in Men we judge there is no uch Salitude exitant or required; Becaue, in Men, that which is Vomited, is either Inipid, or Bitter, or Acid, very rarely, and perhaps never Acidly Salt; the which undoubtedly would happen
if their Pancreatick Juice were Naturally uch.

But being granted, that in men, likewie as in Dogs, it may naturally be Acidly Salt, Whether then will our Hypotheis run? Nowhither: Becaue a Salitude joyned to it, as hereafter hall be declared, doth no way impede its primary Operation.

div.head: CHAP. V. The Liquor of the Glandules in the Body, it demontrated to be neceary, and that the Pancreatick Juyce doth effervee with the Bile.
div.p:
ALL thee things premied, deervedly, who can ask what the Juyce of the Glandules may perform in the bodies of Animals? To whom we hall anwer, that the juyce of all the Conglobated is ubervient to Sanguification, but the liquor of the Conglomerated is ordained to other ues: For that which is generated in the Maxillary Glandules, and other of the Conglomerated, placed about the cavity of the mouth, for the mot part abolveth the Fermentation of Aliments in the Stomach: And that liquor which is generated or eparated in the Conglomerated Glandules of the Pancreas,
eems to us to perform far more: Seeing that Nature for the mot part o wiely dipoeth matters, that one and the ame thing may be accommodated to many.
But eeing the ue thereof is not yet ufficiently known, we hall examine what is firt effued from it into the thin Intertine, and alo happeneth in the ame.

There is a ufficiently large quantity of this Pancreatick juice continually brought to the thin Gut (we remember there hath been collected from one Dog, in the pace of even or eight hours, two Drachms, half an Ounce, and from a Mative an intire Ounce) that it may be continually lifted up, and fermented with the Bile flowing from the ducts of the Liver, to a double or tripple quantity (for as much as we could oberve by the benefit of an intrument applied to their paage into the intetine in Doggs) being therein carried with a certain trugling motion.

That this Effervecency is excited from the acidity of the Pancreatick Juice, and the concoure of the Bile abounding with a fixed and volatile alt, we dare the more freely aert; becaue hitherto we have een no example of an acid pirit concurring with a lixiviate alt to happen without an effevercency ufficiently manifet, o that all impediments were taken away. That both alts are found in the Bile, Chymitry that mot excellent and famous Medical intrument of truth doth prove; by the benefit of which we can eparate a volatile
alt effervecing with an acid pirit, and lixivious alt more manifetly abolving the ame work. But that the Pancreatick Juice containeth in it elf an acidity is manifet by an experiment above-recited; the which, for their akes who are lovers of truth, and whoe belief derogates not from their proper Senes, as in the Academies of divere Regions, we have performed both publickly and privately, we have declared, not again to be repeated: and it is notably confirmed by an experiment which the mot accurate earcher of nature, Floventius Schuyl, in his written Tractate for antient Medicine pag. 94. decribed in thee Words:
div.q: Moreover, I have opened the Abdomen of another Living Dog in the ame Method, and in the Intetinal Bilar Ductus, which is common to the Cytic and Hepatic, by a Compreed Intrument in uch manner as the Figure repreents; that the Pancreatick Juice alone might iue forth, we collected in the pace of nigh three Hours the Quantity of two Ounces of Acidly Sour Juice; whoe manifet Sournes was not only proved by the Tat, but alo by the permixing it with warm Milk; which was o Coagulated, that thereby was formed as it were a Cheee, being a manifet Experiment, that Acidity was altogether prevalent in the ame.
div.p:
Alo, pag. 157. Writing concerning the Pellicle or Bilar Pore of Hores; I, (aith he) by a double Experience, have found that Pellicle, firt of all to be Replenihed with a Humour Subacid,
then with a Bilious Humour, with a Temperate Acidity; into which, in like manner, a Humour, a little Sourih, did flow from the Pancreas, and from thence into the Intetinum Duodenum.

It is likewie concluded, That the Pancreatick Juice, in Men, hath an Acidity in it, not onely from the like nature of all the Bowels and Contents in Brutes and Men, but deduced alo from other Experiments: To wit, by owr Belchings, without the Aumption of owr and acid things into the Stomach; and in the Hypoconders forthwith tretched out, or after Rumbling and Noie, firt oberved in the Belly, preently again breaking out through the Mouth.

Hither alo belong thoe wonderful, and almot inexplicable Motions, and Agitations perceived by the Sick; firt of all about the Region of the Loynes, epecially after any heavy Affliction of the mind, as anger, terror, Fears, occaioned by the acidity of the Pancreatick Juice, flowing into the thin Gut.

If any one object in the Caes now mentioed, that the Pancreatick Juice is evilly dipoed, but that naturally in it elf it containeth no Acidity, let him declare: Dr. Paienius, a man joyn'd to us in peculiar Friendhip, aith, in his Diputation concerning the Vices of Humours, How may that Juice Preternaturally wax foure, if in the ame, the Seeds of Acidity, as we may o call them, were not Prae-exitent. If we tand by Authorities, no doubt but the Caue
will fall: For, Hippocrates de Veteri Med. §. XXIV. againt thoe, openly teacheth, That there is not only in man an Acidity, and that mixed with other things, and therewith o attempered, that it is neither Conpicuous nor Hurtful to a man; but alo ubjoyneth §. XXV. But where the Acidity hall be divided, then it is Conpicuous and Hurtful to man. Hippocrates doth not ay, That it is arien, but eparated: Therefore it is preent in the Natural State, although Inconpicuous.
Beides Galen teacheth that Melancholy is o made of the Blood, as Mut is made of Wine.
