But now with what Probabillity may we ay, That in Wine, Ale, Milk, and the like Liquors, which left to themelves, without the Addition of any other matter, do grow oure; that the acid parts were not before Exitent? What hinders, but that the ame thing may alo happen in men?

Beides the Reaons and Authorities already brought, we will add the following Experiment, which after a wonderful manner doth confirm the natural acidity of the Pancreatick Juice in Men. In the Year 1666. whilt we were reident in the Academy of Andegave, a Shipman, about thirty years of Age; a man of a good Habit of Body, and for as much as we could undertand by the Standers by, very Healthful; in his little Veel, endeavouring to pae under an old Bridge, tanding upon the
River Moene, with his Mat erected, was by the Bridge, unhappily thrown down, which, falling upon the man, killed him; whoe dead Body was immediately brought to the Hopital, where the ame being as yet warm, was opened by Dr. Cronier, the Chyrurgion of the ame Hopital, and our elf; in which we collected the Succus Pancreaticus, which we exhibited to divere curious Tats, who judged it to be acid; and for our own part we freely profes never to have found it more gratefully acid in Dogs.

Who is he, thee things being rightly conidered, that doubteth of the Effervecency happening between the Pancreatick Juice, and the Bile rightly Contituted? Yet, let it hould in any part eem deficient, we will et down, in few words, thoe Primary Objections and Difficulties, both here and in other Countries propoed to us againt this Effervecency; the which being cat off, doubts of leer moment will be ready to fall of their own accord.

The firt Difficulty is, That the Pancreatick Juice, as often as it hath been found by us Inipid, hath not in the leat been able to raie an Effervecency with the Bile in the thin Gut. To this Objection we anwer, That it doth not follow, that the Pancreatick Juice, ometimes found by us Inipid, hould, at that time, have in it no Acidity. Concerning which matter, let them conult Galen De Simp. Med. Fac. Lib. 3. Cap. 13, 14, 15. as alo Hippocrates,
in that place before alledged, aying, That in many mixed things, there are Subtances of various Qualities by Act, in which, nevertheles, thoe Subtances are not ound. The ame is confirmed by daily Experience, whereby it is evident that divere Liquors are rendered inipid, whoe Effects we allow to conit, partly in acid, partly in Lixivious parts; for example, the Spirit of Salt, which is mot harp, may be o dulcified with Spirit of Wine, that no acidity may be perceived in it; yet notwithtanding it failes not to Effervece, if it be permixed with a Lixivious Salt; o alo, in infinite other things, which appear not acid, by reaon of the Acid Particles which are in them, do excite Perceptible Effervecencies both to the Sight and Touch. But we do not abolutely deny, but that the Pancreatick Juice may be ometimes generated o Sluggih, as that it may carcely, indeed not at all ferment with the Bile; but we then judge it to be ditempered or Sick. Yea, that thoe Animals in whom it o happens, do ometimes dye by reaon of the Non-contingent Effervecency: But this doth not detroy the Natural Effervecency.

The Second Difficulty which hath been propoed to me, is, that eeing our Bile and Pancreatick Juice is diluted with the Chyle, they cannot Effervece: But to this Objection we hall anwer; That Oyle of Vitriol, being mingled with Pure water, doth tir up a greater Effervecency with the fileings of Steele, than
if it were mingled therwith alone without Water; and which is yet more, if after the aid Effervecency hath ceaed, if freh Water be added to it, the Oyle of Vitriol, with the Steele Dut, will ferment again afreh. But that we might have an Experiment which might come nearer to our buines, we have taken Cows Milk, as having a very great Affinity with the Chyle, and have poured to it Spirit of Vitriol, mingled with the Lixivious Salt of Tartar, and the Effervecency was preently excited, which continued a great deal longer, than if the Oyle of Vitriol, and Oyle of Tartar per Deliquium, had been mingled without the Milk.

We judge that the long continuance of the Effervecency, ought to be acribed to the Vicidity of the Milk, eeing that daily Experience teacheth us, that Milk, Honey, and other things, may be more, and longer rarified, whilt boyling, than Ditilled Waters, Spirits, and other the like things, not having a Vicidity.

According to which, in the aid Experiment, it is worthy of note, That the Effervecency (perhaps by reaon of the Coagulation of the Milk) doth not o well happen, if the Spirit of Vitriol be put to the Milk, before the Oyle of Tartar per Deliquium: Hence (with the afe Opinion of the more Learned) a Reaon eems to us to be ought into; why commonly, in all Animals, the Ductus Biliarius, either firt, or with the Ductus Pancreaticus, do enter into the Intetine.

From hence may be anwered their Difficulty, who ay, That in ome Animals the Ditance between the Ductus Pancreaticus, and the Ductus Biliatius is too great: It is not neceary, that this Effervecency hould alwayes happen immediately under the Pylorus; but the Matter may be carryed ome fingers breadths further, where at length it may ferment; namely, when the Pancreatick Juice, with the Diluted Bile, is mixed with the Chyle: becaue thoe Animals, in whom o notable a Ditance is found, have alwayes (for as much as we have happened to ee) very long Intetines; as may be een in Coines, Hares, and very many other Animals. Moreover, neither need it be feared, that our determined Effervecency, by which the profitable parts of the Aliment, are eparated from the unprofitable, hould happen too lowly; eeing that in thoe Animals ome one Paage or Channel of the Intetines, may be over and above, ufficient to receive the profitable Particles of the Chyle.

The third Thing which we have oberved is, That the natural heat of our Hand would more increae that Effervecency, than the artificial Heat of Fire. After the ame manner we read in Chymical Books, That the Heat of Hore dung performs many things, which could not be expected from our Artificial Fires, but with the greatet Difficulty.

Which eeing it is o, no man ought to admire, that we are not able to Demontrate the
Effervecency, between the Bile and the Pancreatick Juice, without our Body, whilt they remain in their Temperate and Natural Etate; becaue neither artificial Fire, nor the natural heat of our Hand, can tir up uch a heat as we know to be excited in the Small Gut, by reaon of the Circumjacent Bowels, which are mot hot.

But ome perhaps, being little content with thee Reaons, will ay, That to ee that naturally Effervecency, it behoveth to open a living Dog, eeing that as yet in him the natural Heat is in its Vigour: the which eems to carry omething of force with it, with thoe who conider not that in a Preternatural Dipoition of the Body, we cannot know its natural Operation; as alo with thoe who have never moved their Hand to the Work; becaue thoe things which happen in the Intetines, cannot be een, unles they be opened, and many Veels mut necearily be diected when they are opened, out of which flow uch an abundance of Blood, that it is impoible (as we have often experienced) to ee the deired Effervecency.

Add, that the Succus Pancreaticus cannot after the manner of a ruhing Torrent haten it elf into the thin Intetine, becaue this River flowing as it were from o many Springs and Rivolets, as the Pancreas is environed with Glandules and little branches, doth by a pleaing coure continually lide into its own Channel: So that the cleaned juyce being now effued
with the blood, you cannot without a very tedious delay collect a ufficient quantity of the Pancreatick Juyce to be fermented, and which in the mean time will be o altered by the cold Air, that it will be in vain to expect an Effervecency perceptible to the ight.

For it very much agrees with Vulgar Obervation (aith the mot learned Willis, Exercitat. Medico-Phyic. de anguinis incalecentia, Fol. 85.) That fermentible Liquors when cloed more trickly in the veel, do mot ferment, and preently ceae from their Fermentation, if the Air be admitted through an opened Hole: More-over, Boyles Experiments, Experiment. Phyico-Mechanicor. 41. 42. 43. do mot clearly hew Effervecencies to be excited from the Ebullition of diimilar particles, or by Corroion; alo the Ebullition of Hot water in a glas Sphere to be wonderfully augmented after the Air is ucked out, and that there are ome things which in a pace of time, are intended in the Air to a great Vacuity, whoe action after the air is drawn out, is preently extinguihed: So that without reaon they deire that the Effervecency between the Bile, and the Pancreatick Juyce hould be manifeted to the Eye without the Body: For it is plainly ridiculous to be willing to ee the Effervecency of thoe Humours, and to impede the Humours by which they are performed; or not to admit of the preturnal contitution of the Animal, and willing to ee thoe things
which are performed in the Bowels of Animals.

If their Pancreatick Juyce who deire this thing, were endued with uch an Acrimony as nevertheles being detitute of Natural helps, might ferment with the Bile to the Eye without the Body; with how great pains would not their bowels be tormented, if being helpt by thoe aids in the body, the Effervecency hould be performed; doubtles they would not deire uch an aciditie, before they would ubcribe to our o often commemorated Fermentation, but in hort, would wih for themelves uch a Pancreatick Juyce, as we have above deemed to raie up therein a Natural Effervecency.

Latly, The third difficulty which hath been propoed to us againt the Effervecency between the Bile and the Pancreatick Juyce, is, that the Pancreatick Juyce being acidly alt (as it is ordinarily found in Dogs) ought not to ferment with the Bile: Seeing that the acidite thereof, by reaon of the Salt therein contained, helping the innervated Liquor will be ubdued.

But we may eaily anwer this Objection alo, by ditinguihing Sea-Salts, Foile-Salts, and others compounded of a Lixiviate-Salt, and Acid-Spirit, from the pure Lixiviate Salts. No man will ever deny, but that the lat of Acids doth loe its Force and Energy, and conequently hinders its Effervecency. But that which appertaineth to the firt, of whoe Nature
we eteem that to be which is in the Succus Pancreaticus; (foramuch as we can perceive by the Tat:) All men will eaily grant that that in no wie hindereth the Effervecency, of thoe things, epecially, which have an acid Spirit; as for example, that of Vitriol, in which was diolved Sea-Salt, mixed with the Lixivious Salt of Tartar, or Oyle of Tartar per Deliquium.

Yea it is o far from diminihing the Effervecency, that it exciteth a greater than otherwie would happen; as Sal Armoniack diolved in Oyle of Vitriol, o highly accuates it, that it diolveth Gold, the which without it could not be done. Hence perhaps it commeth to pas, that Dogs, which devour Bones, and other Aliments, of difficult Concoction; which cannot be diolved by an acid Spirit alone; for, the mot part have their Pancreatick Juice acidly-Salt.

Among thoe things which we have aerted, concerning the Pancreatick Juice inipid, acid, alt, &c. it is ufficiently manifet, that the diverity oberved therein, excludes not the Acidity thereof; neither detroyes its Effervecency, which we have taught to be made in the Thin Gut, without any Interruption.

But we have ometimes oberved a pleaant Effervecency of the Bile, with an acid, in the Bile of a Dog, cloed up in a Glas Viall, after having poured on about a third part of Spirit of Niter, and keeping it a while in the warme Rayes of the Sun.

But that we may come nearer to the matter, we will declare the Experiments brought by Dr. Schuylius, to demontrate the Effervecency betwen the Bile, and the Pancreatick Juice, in the preence of many Students; in his Treatie Pro Veteri Med. pag. 88.

q.p:
Therefore (aith he) the Abdomen of a Living Dog being opened, I have bound the Duodenum, not far from the Pylorus with a Ligament; and alo with another a little below the Inertion of the Ductus Pancreaticus: then left the Dog to himelf, his Abdomen being owed up. Three Houres being claped, the Dog, as it eemed, yet living; for he had onely lot ome few drops of Blood: The Abdomen being opened, we found the Space intercepted between the Ligatures, vehemently ditended; o that, it would altogether reit the Compreion of the Fingers, and threatned a Rupture. Neither did we find the Gall Bladder les ditended: Alo that that Intercepted Space of the Duodenum was poeed, with an Intene, and burning heat; in which making a little Wound with the Lancet, the contained Wind, with the Humour, broke forth with a bouncing Noie, alo Vapours and Exhalations; from whence a certain harp tink did trike all our Notrils, the which was greater by the opening of the Intetine; o that, none of the Students tanding by were able to bear it; which was a manifet Argument not only of the large quantity of the Bile, and Pancreatick Juice, which had flown thither: But alo of the Effervecency, which had been in them Excited;
not only to a Mediocrity or Gentlenes, uch as happens in Health, but Vehement: For, that part of the Intetine was not only full, but alo by a certain Force and Fermentation much ditended.

Neither could that part of the Duodenum ditended, have diipated the Wind, Humours, and Exhalations, with o great a Force, unles by the Effervecency or Agitation of the Particles of thoe contrary Humours. Qui cupit, Capiet. A few dayes being pat, I repeated the ame Experiment in the Preence of many Students: And after the pace of two Houres, that Portion of the Intetine, did well in like manner as before, but les hot: But that welling Portion of the Intetine, which before I had bound, being opened, frothing Bubbles broke forth with a noie; the which had o ditended that part of the Intetine, that no man may further doubt of the Certainty of this Effervecency.

div.head: CHAP. VI. What this Effervecency is both in the Sick, and in the Sound; and what Benefit Accrews to the Body thereby.
div.p: SEeing then that it is more than ufficiently evinced, and granted by Reaons and Experiments, that there is an Effervecency between the Bile and the Pancreatick Juice, in the Thin Gutt, and that continually, we will further enquire, what it is in the Sick, what in the Sound, and what Utility it bringeth to Humane Bodies.

In the Sick, we often oberve, That this Effervecency, either by its Fretting, and Tormenting Paines, or ele by Heat or Cold, is very troubleome, as ome Years ince, we knew in our dear Kinman; who ometimes, for a whole week together, came himelf to us, to perceive a cold Ebullition in his Right ide, and that in the place where the Intetinum Duodenum is eated; and the Bile runs together with the Pancreatick Juice; and that afterwards, by the meanes of Medicaments, meanly hot, to be changed into mot hot, continuing a Fortnight, and longer.

That both thee Effervecencies, viz. Cold and Hot, may be excited, is proved by the Thermometry, mot ingenuouly contrived by the Learned Swammerdammius, and depicted in his Treatie of Repiration, Page 108. In the depreed part of which Supream Sphear A. if you mingle together Salt of Tartar, and Spirit of Vitriol, an Effervecency will preently be excited; and uch indeed as will o condene, or thicken the Air contained in that Spheare, that the Water, contained in the lower part of this Intrument B, may acend upward: being a manifet Experiment of Cold, produced by that Effervecency. But, on the contrary, if you mingle Spirit of Tartar with the Spirit of Vitriol, you hall oberve, by the Effervecency excited between them, that the Water is depreed; and the more if with thoe Spirits, you conjyne the Oyle of Turpentine; from whence no man, who is endowed with the lightet Tincture of Philoophy, but will judge, that to proceed from the hot Effervecency, rarifying the Air contained in that Sphear.

Therefore we judge, that in the Sound, that Effervecency happens after a gentle manner, becaue then there is no Sence thereof: The ame thing is to be aid concerning the Motion of the Heart, and beating of the Arteries; the which, although they are Continual, are not perceived by thoe in Health; but when we are evilly dipoed, they ometimes manifet themelves in divere parts of the Body, epecially
in Temples, the Pulation of the Arteries is o manifetly moleted, as if they were contued by ome hard body. By the ame Reaon the Motion of the Heart, is ometime o vehement, that as it hath been oberved by Practitioners, it might in a manner be heard to their Neighbour Houes;Surely this is an Hyperbole. yea it hath ometimes broke the Ribs; as in like manner, we have een at Leyden, in a Baker's Son, dwelling in the Fih-Market; whoe Ribs, by the Vehement Palpitation of the Heart, or rather the Convulive Motion thereof, were Conpicuouly driven outwards; from which Vehement Palpipation, it was freed in a hort time with Medicaments, precribed by Dr. Sylvius; yet not o, but that the Ribs till remained driven outwards.

But now if any ask unto what end and ue this Effervecency between the Bile and the Pancreatick Juyce, being naturally excited, doth happen? We anwer firt of all, that it erves to cut, and attenuate the over vicous pituity adhering to the ides of the Gutts, left they being tufft up, the pores of the Venae Lactea hould be obtructed, or a paage be denied to the Pancreatick Juyce, and the Bile continually liding into the Intetinum Duodenum, or alo, let by the too great abundance of Phlegme, the ence of the Intetines might be obtunded, and their peritaltick Motion either be diminihed, or aboliht, by help whereof, not only the paages of the parts neceary for the nourihing
of the body may be facillitated, but alo the more groer Foecies and unprofitable Excrements may the more commodiouly be eparated; which ue Gallen hath acribed to the Bile alone, as not knowing the Pancreatick Juyce, firt by us dicovered, nor the Effervecency excited between it and the Bile: Therefore he aith in Lib. 5. De uu partium, cap. 4.

q.p: A neceary Excrement (to wit Phlegme) of this ort, is to be found both in the Stomach and in the Intetines, as we have elewhere demontrated: but that it may be generated, both Anatomy, and thoe Dieaes to which men are daily ubject from the abundance of the uperfluities hereof do declare: The Cure whereof is imple, to wit, by the Exhibition of thoe things which have power to divide, to cut and cleane vicous matters.

For that caue therefore Nature hath from the beginning provided a Defence for them, that this Juyce being harp, might be cleaned, and as it ought be altogether eparated from the body, not into any Intetine near the Anus; but into the firt Intetine taking its beginning from the Pylorus, neither ometimes may it want the external Help of ome of the inferiour Intetines. Moreover, as long as the body is rightly governed, the pituitous Excrement is daily cleaned. But when it is more copiouly collected by ome evil affection of the body, the mot famous Phyicians doubt nothing, but that thoe mot
grievous Dieaes which happen to the belly, as the Ileum, Lienteria, and Tenemus, may be occaioned by it. Neither therefore is that Tranlation to be contemned which Nature hath provided for Health, by the opportune immiion of the Bilious paage in Animals.

div.p: The ame Office is no les to be acribed to the Pancreatick Juyce, then to the Bile hereafter to be made conpicuous by the Decription of its acid Qualities. Before we go any further in declaring the Effects ariing from this Effervecency, we will premie ome Fermentations, that thee things being with all poibility inpected, it may become the more obvious, what benefit the Intetinal Effervecency bringeth to the Aliments after their propulion to the Gutts.

As many as have mingled filings of Steel with Oyl of Sulpher, prepared Per Campanum, or Spirit of Vitriol, having added a ufficient quantity of water, they might oberve an Effervecency to be excited after a certain manner by the concoure of thoe contraries; by help whereof, the laudable parts of the Steel are joyned to the acid Spirits, whilt the ret counted as refue, do partly go to the bottome, and partly like Froth wim or flote upon the Liquor.

But I think that the more purer parts of the Steel, and thoe mot exactly mixed, are therefore joyned to the acid Liquor, becaue they have therewith a more greater affinity, becaue
of which they uffer themelves to be diolved; but not the other more Impure and les mixed among them, whether they be more Terrene, and therefore eek the bottome, or whether they they be more Oleus, and therefore Supernatant.

The ame, greater or leer, Affinity of Acids, with the diolved Matter, doth further appear, if in the ame Liquor more Mettals be ucceively immitted; Firt, thoe which have a lee; afterwards, thoe which have a greater Affinity with it: So, when Silver is put into Aqua-Fortis, and o long detained therein, till it be all diolved; which Effervecency, is abolved with its Coagent: hence let Copper be put to the afore-aid Solution, the Aqua-Fortis will leave the Silver, and begin a new Effervecency with the Copper, whilt that the Silver, being gradually neglected by the Aqua-Fortis, gets to the bottome; which Mutation, by the Chymits, is called by the name of Precipitation.

But if afterwards, you cat Iron to this Solution of Copper, the ame thing will again come to pas, and by degrees the Copper will be precipitated to the bottom. Which if again, to the Solution of the Iron, you affue ome Lixivium of Calcind Tartar, Vine Ahes, or the like, the Acid Spirit will joyne it elf more trictly to the Solution of that, than of the other Mettalick bodies, and will carcely uffer it elf to be eparated from the ame.

The Reaon of this more traight Union is to be required from the more pure Acid Spirit, that is les mixed, and therefore more narrowly joynes it elf with the aid Lixiviate fixed Salt, hitherto alo more pure and les mixed, than with the ame Salt; but les pure, that is more mixed: So that, here the purity of the contrary Parts ought to be undertood by their Affinity.

By reaon of this greater Affinity, the Oyle of Tartar prepared per Deliquium, (which is nothing ele but the Salt of Tartar, diolved by the Humidity of Air) when it is in like manner poured with the Vitriol into Water, it joyneth it elf to the acid Spirit, exiting in the Vitriol, whilt its Sulphureous part, as having a leer Affinity with Acidity, by little and little departs, and gets to the bottom.

Which being permied we will conider, what things may happen in the Aliments in the Stomach by its Fermentation, and what alo befalleth the ame; (after the aforementioned Fermentation) in the thin Gut epecially, that we may conclude omething more certain, and more probable than uual. Firt, The Stomach, being opened, together with the Guts, eeing that the Aliments, by an abolute Fermentation, are wont to be driven from the Stomach to the Intetines, we have oberved a notable Change between that which is contained in the Stomach, and that in the Guts: For, that in the Stomach hath had a more groer, and Vicid
Conitence, and by the Diverity of the Aliments, and other things aumed, a divere Colour, and oftentimes les White.

Certainly, this Mutation cannot be derived from any other thing than from the Bile, and Pancreatick Juice: Becaue thoe Humours only flow in a large Quantity to the Superiour part of the mall Gut, and are admixed with the Aliments.

The Examen of both the afore-aid Liquors, doth confirm this our Opinion: For, the Bile, abounding with a Volatile Salt and Oyle, hath a force of Inciding, Attenuating, and making Fluid mot things where-with it is permixed, epecially uch as are pituitous; as Galen alo teacheth, Lib. V. De uu Part. Cap. IV. as by the place above quoted may be een, to which Platerus ubcribes, Cap. VIII. concerning the Defect of Hearing by the Repletion of the Eares, whilt he breakth out into thee Words:

q.p: Firt, he declares that Aqua Mula, or Hydromel, or if to cleane more powerfully, with the Decoction, or bitter Juice before-mentioned, of Worm-Wood, Centaury, or Lupines, that may be effected, adding Honey or Gall, which, above all other things, as hath been often aid doth make thoe things, which are Vicous, Fluid, &c.

div.p:
But the Succus Pancreaticus, being pregnant with a Subacid Spirit, as appeareth by the Precedent Reaons, and Experiments, doth in like manner augment the Vicidity of the
Aliments by the Solution of their Fluidity; the which being o as it is more than ufficiently known, we will not delay time, by further proofs concerning the Manner, wherby Acids in the thin Gut, do return to a Liquid, and Fluxile Motion, or other-wie to an Ine • t and Pituitous Vicidity; we hall only ay that in our Judgement it o happeneth; for as much, as by the Tenuity, and Sharpnes of the Parts, tirred up by the Effervecency, the Phlegme is thereby as with Swords, incided, and attenuated into very Minute Parts. That which attaineth a Whitih Colour, then obervable in the more Fluid part of the Aliments, we think it deducible from the Acidity of the Pancreatick Juice; becaue we may note, that many other things, abounding with a Lixivious Salt and Oyle, do wax White upon the affuion of Acids: So, that Vinegar or Sharp Wine, being poured upon common Sulpher, diolved with any Lixivium, and grown Red, that Reddih Colour is o changed, that it is made almot like to Milk: Wherefore alo it is called by the Chymits Lac Sulphuris. The ame is apparent in the Reinious Extracts of Vegitables, as alo in Spirit of Hart's Horne or Soot, being Replete with much Volatile Salt; with which an Acid Spirit being mixed, acquires a Milky Colour. All thoe things being rightly conidered, we judge, Secondly, That the Effervecency, in the thin Gut is exceeding neceary for the right Separation of the profitable Parts from the unprofitable. But
perhaps ome, who are altogether wedded to Antiquity, admitting nothing which to them is Novel, becaue they have read or undertood nothing, in the Antients, concerning this our expected Secretion, by Fermentation, will not think that uch a preparation is required to eparate the profitable parts of the Aliment from the unprofitable; but that the alteration which is performed in the Stomach, is ufficient to this purpoe; in which, if any thing be wanting, it may be Conummated by the Peritaltick Motion of the Guts; by the help whereof its more Fluid parts are thrut forward into the Milky Veines, the Foeces, with the remaining thicker and leer profitable parts, paing away by the Channel of the Intetines.

To the which we deny not, but that omething is contributed to this matter both by the aid Fermentation and the Peritaltick Motion of the Guts; nevertheles we do not think that any Phyitian, unles a Slave to the Antients, amongt all thoe things which are daily oberved in the diecting of Brute Animals, and Medical Practis; or at leat-wie may be oberved, will reject this caue propoed by us; If, firt of all, he diligently conider, that in the Coeliack Flux the Aliments, ometimes vicid like a Pultis, and every where alike, and ometimes mixed with a whitih Liquor are purged out.

But this Diverity of Colour happens, by a Contingent, or Non-contingent, Secretion of
profitable parts from the unprofitable, by the aid Effervecency; which, who can but in vain, Attribute to expreion alone.

Yet we deny not, that by the Fermentation of Aliments alone, rightly performed in the Ventricle, omething Fluid may, Spontaneouly, pas away from the ret of the Aliments more Pultatious; nevertheles that is but little, if it be compared with the large quantity of noble Chyle, which is continually trained through the Venae-lacteae, or alo from thence wimming up in the Caeliack Flux; o that, then the more watery part of the Chyle, freely going forth by the Compreion of the Bowels alone, is more without Effervecency, than the other which is more white, or, as we may ay, more Milky.

In that Spontaneous Separation of the parts wont to happen through Fermentation, the Spirituous indeed firt go forth with the Watery, neceary for the Reparation of the Animal pirits: We have an example in the Fermentation of Plants, & other things, abounding with a Volatile Spirit, in which the Spirituous Particles, alwayes expanded, and endeavouring to flee through the Pores of the Stomach and Guts, being looed from their Fetters, ruh through the Pores: From whence we are fully perwaded, that after the Aumption of the mot Spirituous Aliments, a uddain trength is found in men; and although it be Inconpicuous to our Bodily Eyes, that the Spirits, by the ame reaon, are diffued through the Pores of the Body; nevertheles,
after a manner, we undertand it with the Eyes of our Mind, whilt we ee a Stupendious Vertue in ome Medicaments externally applyed: The ame thing is often oberved by Anatomits, when after the Inciion of the Peritonaeum, they receive the Foetid Flatulencies paing through the Tunicles of the Guts to the Notrils.

But becaue the Spirituous and Volatile parts are not ufficient to utain Life; but, Moreover, Acid, Oleous, and Salt parts, are alo required; therefore there is need of a new Alteration of things aumed, that thoe parts, by a decent Copiounes, might be eparated from the Superfluous and Unprofitable: Which alteration we call Effervecency, and by help of which, we judge (with our ometimes Famous Profeor Franci. de le Boe-Sylvius, from whoe Lectures, as well publick as private, we do not deny to have drawn many Fundamentals of this Doctrine) that Secretion to be accomplihed.

We do not only judge by that Effervecency mediateing the more Subtile and Fluid parts of Aliments, but alo the Pituity by the help thereof diolved in the thin Gut, part of which is carryed together, with the better Portion of the Bile, and Succus Pancreaticus, through the Vermiculous crut of the Intetines into the Milky Veines; from hence to the Citerne or Common Receptacle of the Chyle, and Lympha, placed in the Region of the Loynes under the Appendices of the Diaphragma; and
from thence acends through the Chyliferus, or more rightly the Lymphatick Ductus, Thoracicus, (becaue it continually carryeth the Lympha, and the Chyle, only by Intervals) to the Subclavian, or left Jugular Veine, that from thence it may decend, with the Blood, through the Superiour Trunck of the Vena Cava, decending into the right Eare of the Heart, and the right Ventricle thereof. And in the right Ear, and right Ventricle of the Heart, it is confued both with the acending and decending Blood, and alo impregnated with the Pancreatick Juice, the Bile, Phlegme, and Lympha; from whence it acquires a requiite Conitency of Blood.
This confirms what we have aid; That any thing acid Coagulates all Fatnes and Oyle.

But becaue, on the other ide, the aforeaid humours have in themelves a force of attempering, we need not fear too great a Conitency of the Blood; o long, as at leat they remain in a Laudable and Natural Etate.

But eeing that the more fluid and more profitable parts, as well of the Aliments aumed, as of the three nominated Humours, do go to the Heart; the ret more gros, and les profitable, by the Peritaltick Motion of the Guts, gradually without Sene, are driven forwards to the thick Guts, where they are ditinguihed by the name of Alvinary Foeces. Whether alo the Exhalations, excited by this Effervecency,
or even the Juice it elf may not afford a natural Fermentation in the Stomach, we dare not as yet aert; although ome Animals eem to perwade it to us, of both whoe Ducts, to wit, the Pancreatick and Bilar, Nature hath determined a paage into the Stomach. We judge this Pancreatick Juice is not onely Subervient to the Functions, already declared, but alo by the Sub-acid Spirit with which it is impregnated by the mot wie God, we think it to be ordained after a certain manner, to Incraate, and Inpifate the more fluid Bile, and alo to temper its too much Acrimony; This thing is manifet in the Bile by affuing any acid Spirits thereto, which preently, either more or les, will be thickned, and its more gros part precipitated to the bottom, whilt its Thinner part floats on the top like Phlegme. Hence peradventure Hippocrates, Lib. De Victu Accutorum, Text 29. 8. 9. teacheth that bitter things are diolved, and pas into Phlegme, that is, They become luggih whiles they are pread or mixed with an acid, which is not only confirmed by the Authority of the Divine old Gentleman, but alo by a daily Effervecency; whereby it is evident that Acids, and Salts, being put into a Conflict amongt themelves, do o infringe their harp Particles, that they become almot temperate: Wherefore not without Reaon Hipp. Aph. I. Sect. VI. hath taught us in the daily Levities of the Intetines, That if an Acid belching hould upervene, which had not been before, we ought
to hope well: For it is a igne that the Pancreatick Juice, by its acidy, will, in a hort time, attemper the Acrimony of the Bile.

We have aid that the Pancreatick Juice is ordained by Nature, after a ort to incraate the more Fluid Bile; but it may alo o happen that the Bile, by its Acidity, may be rendered more Fluid, viz. when the Vicidity of the Bile dependeth upon the Vicidity of Phlegme; therefore in one repect Acids may render the bile more gros, but in another more Fluid; for Acids do incraate Fats, and Lixivious Salts.

Among thoe things which we have now recited, it is ufficiently evident, in the Humours naturally contituted in the mall Gut, and the Friendly Effervecency of Nature from thence occurring, that many Functions in the Body are rightly performed; which by the aid Effervecency evilly happening, are wated, and become Vitious. The verity of which thing, that we may make it more clearly appear, we hall, firt of all, declare ome Vices which happen in the Subtance of the Pancreas. Secondly, We hall adjoyne thoe things which may befall the Juice thereof.

div.head: CHAP. VII. With what Dieaes the Subtance of the Pancreas, and its Juice may be Moleted.
div.p: CErtainly not a few, to whom the Pancreatick Juice hath been unknown, have nevertheles believed that the Caues of many grievous Dieaes lay hid. For, Schenkius in his Exer • itatione, Anat VI. Lib. I. Sect. II. Cap. XXI. aith, And there are the Seats (meaning the Pancreas, and the Meentery) of innumerable and wonderful Dieaes; for the earching of which, the age of one man is not ufficient. Which thing, being the Scorne of Phyitians, alo cateth thoe which are mot exercied into a Bluhing hue.

Fernelius alo Lib. VI. Pathol. Cap. VII. peaking concerning the Dieaes of the Pancreas and Meentery, doth affirm and profes, That he hath thought for the mot part, thee to be the Seats of Choler, Melancholy, Diarhaea, Dienteria, Cachexia, Atrophia, of Languihing, of Light, and Erratick Feavers: Latly, the Caues of hidden Dieaes; by the driving away of which, Health might be retored to the Afflicted.

And Riolanus, that Egregious Ornament of the Univerity of Lovaine. V. F. Plempius, with other Famous men, alo Converant in Practie, do alo think that the caue of intermitting Feavers, of Hypocondriack Melancholy, and other Chronick Dieaes, do lurk, or lye hid in the Pancreas. But this buines, without all doubt, had been more uccesfully treated of both by thee, and other men of no mall Merit in Medicine, had the Pancreatick Juice, with its Generation and Nature, been known to them: Wherefore we hall endeavour, being excited by their Commendable Examples, to produce omething to the Learned World for the Common good, by conidering firt, By what Dieaes the Subtance of the Pancreas may be infeted. Secondly, By declaring the Primary Vices, which may happen to its Juice. Thirdly, By earching into the Functions, which are hurt by its evil Dipoition. Fourthly, By invetigating the Dieaes which follow thoe Functions hurt. Fifthly, and latly, By delivering the Remedies wherewith all of them may be amended. The Dieaes wherewith the Subtance of the Pancreas is wont to be moleted, are Obtructions, and thoe which follow them, Tumours, Schirous's, Abces's, Stones, &c. Obtructions may happen to the Pancreas two wayes: Firt, In the Ductus, when the Pancreatick Juice cannot freely pas through it, into the Intetines, even as we hall more clearly Demontrate to happen when we hall dicoure
of Intermitting Feavers. Secondly, In the Subtance of the Pancreas it elf, when by any caue, either Internal or External, the Circulation of the Blood through it, is hindered; from whence the Parenchyma, by the continual appule of blood, is puffed up, and wells, unles it be indurated, or by a previous Inflamation goes into an Abeeus.

Which, that it may be made known to all, we will bring upon the Stage the Obervations of everal Phiitians, and Anatomits. Riolanus, Anthropog. Lib. 2. Cap. 10. writeth, that he had oberved in many people, who were of a Melancholy Nature, and Habit of Body, that the Pancreas equalled the weight of the Liver; and alo confirms the ame, by the Example of the mot Illutrious Augutinus Thuanus; Who, by the Melancholy Habit of Body, did complain for four Years together of a Collick Pain, about the Region of the Colon, with a Sene of a Burden, or Weight, at his Stomach, while he tood upright, or walked: But his Hypoconders did not well: At length being taken with an unlookt-for Gangreen, from his right Foot uddainly to the Superiour parts with Horrible and Direful Pains, in the pace of Six Hours expired. His Body being opened, and the Liver taken out, was round like to a Sphare, tuffe with Fat, and tran-fixed with a certain pituitous hardned Matter like to Mortar: But the Pancreas, by its Amplitude and Weight, did equalize the Liver, wholly Schirhous with many
little Knobs, which were filled with the Species of a Pigeons Egg; the Spleen was o wated that it carce weighed an Ounce.

For which reaon, ome have called the Pancreas, the Vicar or Supply of the Spleen; not conidering that this Diverity might happen to other parts alo; and likewie in Doggs, after the Extirpation of the Spleen, the Subtance of the Pancreas did in no wie grow into a greater weight; which, according to them, ought to happen, if the Pancreas upplyed the Office of the Spleen.

Aubertus relates a tory of an Abceus Progym. ad lib. abdit. Fernelij Exercit. 44. of a certain Merchant of Lyons, which could never leep, and when he endeavoured to leep, he fell into a Lipothymie, and cold weat of the whole Body, till at length he dyed. His Body being opened there was only found a putrid Abceus in the Pancreas; the Stomach and other principal parts being afe. Guilh. Fabric. Hildanus. Cent. 1. Oberv. 71. alo relates, that he, in a certain Carpenter, who for the pace of two years, by Intervals, was grieved with divers Dieaes, laboured under Obtructions, and Cachexy: Found in his dead Body, among other things, a Schirhous Tumour, uppurated like unto a Collection of Fat, under the skin, about the bignes of two Fits; having its rie from the Inferiour part of the Pancreas, which incloed the Intetinum Duodenum; o that, being covered with the Peritonaeum, it alo reembled another Ventricle.

You may read of a Cancerous Ulcer of the Pancreas, mot worthy of note, in the Curious Micellanies Medico-phys, of the Germans, (which as in the year 1670. by great Dilligence, they began to bring to Light: So we altogether deire that the great God, for Common benefit, may proper their Endeavours:) Oberv. 99. where Dr. J. Fera. Hert. à Tottenfeld adjoyns thee following things, which they found in the Cavity of the Thorax in a certain Chyrurgion after Death.

q.p: Coming to the Lower Belly, we aw that Fleh perforating the Diaphragma to be the Pancreas, which was the length of two Spans, and breadth of two Hands tranvere, being putrid, and corrupted; which, by its Coroive Acidity, did not only perforate the Diaphragma, but did alo o corrode the Spina Dori, that a Cancer-like lcer was produced, with a light troke the whole Spina Dori might eaily be broken. Latly, it corroded the very Vena Cava it elf, which runs into the Spine; by which the Blood, flowing through the Diaphragma, brought Death by impeding the Motion of the Lungs. This Cancer of the Pancreas, by creeping further, did alo corrupt both the Kidneys, and caued them to be mot black and putrid.

div.p:
We add more-over, that which the mot Famous Highmore, Corp. Hum. Diq. Anat. lib. I. part II. writeth that he oberved, In a Noble Woman, which being Antient, laboured with Convulions, Epilepie, and the Hyterick Paion; and at length, after Exquiite Paines
and Torments, changed Life with Death; in whoe dead Body, being opened, we found the Pancreas onely evilly affected and exulcerated.

They which deire more Examples of Exulceration, let them read Barthol. Hit. Johan. Dan. Hortij Oberv. Anatom Salmuth, Tulpium, Blaij Comm. in Synt. Anat. Veting
and others. That this Pancreas had obtained a tony hardnes, in an Antient Roman. Woman, is witneed by Dr. Panarol; as is likewie to be een in Dr. Blaius, in his Commentaries, even now cited page 40. In like manner, in the Year 1667. the following Hitory was Communicated to us at Paris, Bona fide, by Dr. Gajen, a Chyrurgion, and Famous Anatomit, by him before oberved:

A Noble Man, aged about thirty, being Melancholy, was Obnoxious to Catthars, by the intemperate ue of Wine, and Fruits; continually aumed, fell into a Vomiting, and Diarhaea, whereby after ome pace, there followed a Flux of Blood; from whence, more and more failing in Strength, the Tenth day he Changed Life with Death. His body being opened, he found in the Pancreas, about the end of the Ductus Pancreaticus going into the Intetines, even or eight Stones, having the bignes of the larget Peae; ome of which being given us by himelf, we keep among our Rarities.

Nevertheles, this Obervation to us, eemed not o wonderful, who believe that Stones
are generated in all the Glandules of the Body, epecially in the pineal Glandule: becaue in it we have more than twenty times oberved Stones in men, extinguihed either by a gentle Dieae, or a violent Death; which thing happens more frequently in France, than in Holland; a more profitable account whereof, we do not ee, than that the Anima of the French, as by Nature more Volatile, may be bound to a more firm Reidence in their Bodies.

We have alo found in a certain Dog, in that part of the Ductus Pancreaticus, where the Acending concurs with the Decending, and is only imple; a Cartilagineous Excrecency, about the Ductus and its end, which like a Nipple, did hang out into the Intetine, to the bignes of a Finger, in the middle whereof a ufficient paage was afforded to the liding Pancreatick Juice. Riolanus l. c. found the whole Pancreas hardned like a Cartilage.

We might be able to inferr many Dieaes of the Pancreas, were it not already ufficiently evident by what hath been aid, That the Pancreas alo may be afflicted with common Dieaes; neither that its evil Contitution followeth the affections of the Liver or Spleen: For, ometimes the other Bowels being unhurt, the Pancreas alone, hath been the caue of Death, for Reaons (already) ufficiently alleadged.

For which reaon, it is manifet that the Pancreas is neceary to Life, which is alo confirmed by an Experiment made by us at Paris, in the Year 1667. when in the Houe of Dr. Bourdelot, where, every Monday, the mot Curious of Phyitians and Phyloophers did meet, we had for three Months together expoed this little Book, in the French Tongue, to publick Examination, ome being led by Speculation alone, aerted that Animals might live no les without the Pancreas, than the Spleen: For which caue, before all that Company, we extirpated the Spleen, and alo mot exactly the Pancreas, of a certain Dog: The Abdomen again being cloed, Dr. Bourdelot commanded his Servants to keep the Dog mot diligently, who, notwithtanding all their Dilligence, in a hort time Dyed.

Thoe Vices being declared, which ometimes befall the Subtance of the Pancreas, we hall proceed to thoe things which may happen to its juice; from whence, not a few Natural Functions depending upon its Natural Dipoition, are wated and hurt. Firt of all; The Pancreatick Juice offendeth when it is more paringly effued into the thin Gut, which ometimes comes to pas by the more paring Generation, or Separation thereof in the Pancreas; or when there is an Obtruction in one or more of its lateral Branches; becaue, for a time the Juice is therein tagnated, till at length the Obtruction is opened.

It is more paringly generated, when the Matter thereof is more or les deficient in the blood, and not being retored with convenient Aliments; or when the ame is carryed off another way; or when it is more trictly conjoyned with the blood, that it cannot be ufficiently eparated from it. One or more of the Ducts of the Pancreas are obtructed by a pituitous, and vicid Matter, together with the Matter of the Pancreatick Juice, eparated in the Pancreas, and tranlated into, and detained in thoe Ducts.

Secondly, The Pancreatick Juyce doth alo offend, when it is carryed into the Intetines in greater plenty, whether it be generated more Copiouly, or for a time being detained by Stagnation, in one or more of the Laterall Ducts, is then more plentifully Effued, when the Obtruction is Diolved.

It is generated more plentifully by reaon of the Liberal ue of acid Aliments, or at leat of Condited Acids; for example, oure Wine, Vinegar, Pomecitrons, &c. as alo, by reaon of ome Vice of the Glandules, by which the Separation of that juice, from the blood is promoted; as alo, ometimes perhaps, becaue of more larger Veels tending into the Pancreas, and as is uual, affording a larger Matter to the juyce.

Thirdly, When it flows inequally into the thin Gut, that is, at one time more abundantly, at another more paringly: Which, firt of all,
pens by an Obtruction of one or more of the Lateral Ducts, which continuing, nothing floweth out from them; and therefore a more paring juyce is then effued into the whole:

By the aid Obtruction, any way removed, preently that which was tagnant in the middle Duct, together with the ret of the juice, is effued into the thin Gut; from whence, on the contrary, the Excretion of the Pancreatick juice is then more plentiful.

That uch an Obtruction may ometimes happen in the Lateral Ducts of the Pancreas, Reaon doth perwade, and Experience it elf confirmeth, even as we hall more clearly evince in the following Dicoure of Intermitting Feavours.
Fourthly, It offendeth when it is more Fluid and Liquid, than Natural: which happeneth by reaon of uch blood, or animal Spirits, more Copiouly mixed there-with.
Fifthly, It offendeth, when on the contrary it is more Vicid; by reaon of the Blood, likewie Vicid, and abounding with much pituity.
Whence it is one while les acid, another while more acid; one while alt, another while autere; ometimes of a imple Tat, or ele Compounded of thoe before-named.

The Nominated Juice is les acid, either bebeaue of the animal Spirits, more plentifully carried to the Pancreas, or for want of acidity in the Blood; whether it may come to pas, by reaon of auming things unfit to repair the acidity taken away, or by the ue of uch things as infringe, concentrate, obtund, or extinguih acidity.

The acidity of the Pancreatick Juice augmented, for the mot part, is to be acribed to the Redundancy of acid Humours in the Body; ometimes to the Impedited Afflux of the Animal Spirits to the Pancreas; at leat-wie, to that part of the Juyce which is tagnant in the Lateral Ducts; or other-wie, perhaps, by reaon of the Animal Spirits, being Exhauted. An acid Humour is wont to abound in the Body, for the mot part, from aumed Aliments, Sauces, or Medicaments, which are harp, with harp Wines, uch as for the mot part is Renih, Moellanous, &c. as alo, becaue of a more Cold Air, and North Wind, Sorrow of Mind though not over much, &c. The motion of the Animal Spirits, to the Pancreas, is impedited, when the Animal Spirits are defective; or being more dull or low throughout the whole Body; alo, when the Nerves are obtructed, diecated, or compreed.

The Succus Pancreaticus is made Salt by a Marine, or Foile Salitude, in like manner, becaue of the Seroity of the Blood likewie Salt; perhaps by a like Fault of the Glandules
concurring; for which reaon, the Secretion of the Saline parts from the Acid, cannot be abolved: For, our common Salt coniteth of two parts, to wit, a Lixivious Salt, and an Acid Spirit joyned together. The auterity of the Pancreatick Juice eemeth to us, to be deduced from the more gros, or Terrene Particles, with which its acid Particles are involved; which appeareth, not only in Fruits, being firt oure, afterwards, when by the gentle Heat of the Sun, they are Ripened, they are made a little more acid; and at length, when the more gros Particles thereof, by the Agitation of Heat, are more exalted, they become Sweet.

But moreover it is manifet, that thoe things which are ower, it is by their Syncriis and Diacriis: So D. Paienus hath noted in Thei. XXI. C. that the juyce of Ribes, being powred to Coral of a grateful acid, becomes autere. Vitriol and Allum ditilled, yield an acid Spirit: Likewie an acid Spirit may be ditilled from ealed Earths, Bole Armeniack, and the like; but how Bole Armen. may by the help of Nitre and other things, be made more atringent, is to be een in Le Febre, in his French Edition. Page 649.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The Functions which are vitiated by the Pancreas, or it's Juyce evilly dipoed.
div.p: HAving declared the more grievous Vices wherewith the Pancreas and its Juyce are wont to be affected, every man may ee, that from that Fountain very many Incommodities to Mortals do proceed; all which things, eeing we have propoed to handle them in order, we hall firt judge of thoe which proceed from the Pancreas it elf, by ubjoyning thoe things which are wont to flow from its juyce.

If the Pancreas acquire a Schirrous ubtance reembling Stones, and alo weighty in the place where it hould defend the Sanguinous Veels, as ome would have it, let they hould be hurt by the Vertaebrae, or other parts, it will greatly afflict them by Compreion, and will hinder the circular motion of the Blood, from whence divers Ditentions, Inflammations, Obtructions, and other things arie, and pring up, fit to impedite the Common ue of the Bowels. Beides alo by its weight, it will not a little hinder the Stomach from performing its Office by compreing it; but when it is inflamed,
or Apothumated, for the mot part it will caue the ame Incommodities with the other Bowels, being afflicted with the ame Vice. But ome may ay, if uch grievous Effects happen to the Pancreas, how can the ue thereof be o neceary, and how do we hitherto live o long with them? Then may we alo demand how thoe men may live, to whoe Brain, Heart, Liver, and other bowels neceary to Life, the ame, or the like things happen, and we hall further enquire of them, by what reaon uch may live well or ill? The Hitories above do certainly tetifie, that uch live a mierable life, and when the Evil hall be increaed, thoe alo for no other Caue have changed Life for Death: So that from that part can nothing be infer'd againt our Hypotheis.

Having unfolded the Incommodities ariing from the Parenchyma of the Pancreas it elf, it remaineth, that we alo run through the functious Hurt, which the evil Qualities, or Vices of the Pancreatick Juyce, or other Humours exiting in the thin Gutt, do draw after them.

Therefore the Pancreatick Juyce being driven to the Intetines in a leer quantity, will not ufficiently free the Gutts from the uperfluous Humidity in them, and o will occaion many Obtructions, as the Learned R. Lower, who judgeth this juyce to be ordained by Nature to cleane the Chyle; he writeth in his Treatie of the Heart, Chap. 5. page 215. that
by the defect thereof, he hath oberved Obtructions of the Venae Lacteae, in thee very words.

q.p: It eems to me mot true, that that great Glandule (namely the Pancreas) is eated in that place; and that Ductus to be opened into the Intetines, that the Lympha (for o he calleth the Pancreatick Juyce) being there eparated, may be mixed with the decending Chyle, whereby it may more readily enter, and more expeditely pas through the narrow Channel of the Lactean Veins; and indeed the Chyle in the Milkey Veels, either becaue of its cracitie, or for want of potulent Liquor (which ought to be for its Vehicle) may ometimes be apt to be tagnant, and o concrete, and by the ame reaon, to top, and altogether fill up thoe Veels, as in a Dog, whoe Pancreas was obdurated I once oberved.

div.p:
Neither alo will it ufficiently promote the Natural, and due Separation of the Chyle from the Excrements, and that epecially if the Aliments be more dry, or of a more difficult Fermentation: Hence necearily follows a diminihed Nutrition of the whole body, as alo a univeral Languihing; o that, uch may rather be aid to draw Life, than to live. But the Pancreatick Juice, being eparated in a larger quantity; and brought to the Intetines, will, as it were, pare off, not only their uperfluous Pituity, but alo that neceary part which hould defend them from Injuries like a Curry-Comb; and beides, it will eparate more than it ought, from the aumed Aliments, o
that, ometimes the unprofitable, and excrementitious parts, together with the profitable, may be conveyed to the Mas of Blood; ometimes only the profitable Parts, but in a larger quantity than they hould, may be carryed by the ame wayes: From whence, if here we ay a Pethora will happen, and thence a Cacochymy, Who can overthrow our Aertions? More-over, we think that the Lancionations, in the left Hypocondria, firt moleted by coures, do proceed from too great a quantity of the Bile and Pancreatick Juyce, eparated from the Blood, by a more vehement Motion of the Body, and the tirring up a greater Effervecency.

For, it is mot certain, that Running, or any other vehement Exercie of the Body, doth accelerate the Motion of the Blood, through the whole Body; which, eeing it is the caue of the Separation of thee or other Humours, then it is alo neceary, that thoe Humours be depoited into the Guts in a greater plenty; which, being eparated in a Natural Quantity, and Quality, if, as we have already proved, they may excite a natural and friendly Effervecency to Nature, may not the contrary happen when they are otherwie dipoed by exciting an Effervecency, greater, and troubleome to Nature? After a wonderful manner doth that place confirm this our Opinion, in which thoe paines are perceived by coure, and very ordinarily, though unjutly, are acribed to the Spleen; becaue the Spleen is not in that
place, where thoe pains do in us excite a Moletation, but hath its eat more down-wards; becaue in that place thoe paines do manifet themelves in the Anteriour part of the Hypocondria, where the thin Gut M, emerging under the Meentery N, doth lye by the Peritonaeum, as is to be een in the firt Table, where we have Delineated to the Life the Scituation of that Intetine.

The inequal eparation of the Succus Pancreaticus, and propulion thereof, to the Intetines, produceth various Mutations in the Guts, and ele-where, concerning the uddain Happening of which, no man will ever aigne a fit Reaon, who will not give heed to thoe things. Hence we think to be deduced the uddain Deliquiums of the Wind ometimes advening, erratick Feavers, intermitious of Pules, &c.

The Pancreatick Juice being more fluid, will more dilute the Pituity of the Guts, and perhaps ometimes occaion the Flux of the Belly; epecially if it be conjoyned with a Salitude, by whoe acrimony the Guts are provoked to their Contraction; and unles that Flux of the Belly follow the Peritaltick Motion of the Guts, it will necearily expres a greater Quantity of Chyle into the Venae Lacteae, from whence the ame incommodities will arie, which we have deduced from the Pancreatick Juyce, eparated in too large a Quantity.

The more Vicid Pancreatick Juice concreting by the leat external Cold, will occaion Obtructions, as alo intermitting Feavers, and likewie atringe the Belly. Concerning the enible Qualities, and firt of the Rellih, there is ometimes produced a Pancreatick juyce les acid; from whence there is neither a due Effervecency in the Duodenum, and therefore not a neceary Separation of the profitable parts from the unprofitable, nor a deired Conitency betowed on the Blood: and therefore they, in whom uch Blood is, have been les able to reit Petilential Venom, than thoe in whom, by the laudable Acidity of their Pancreatick Juice, have alo a more Laudable and greater Conitency of their Blood. Hence the reaon is alo clear, Why Melancholly Men are les afflicted with the Plague, than thoe who are endued with a Bilious blood.

For we think that no man may be infected with the Plague, o long as the Natural conitency of his blood is preerved: We aert this the more freely, becaue we ee the blood in all perons infected with the Plague to be altered, and obtain a far more fluid conitency: So that if ometimes by chance, Negligence, Ignorance, or any other urging Caue; as for example, too great a Plethory, pitting of blood bringing a preent danger to Life, let a Vein be opened, the blood flowing out although refrigerated; nevertheles, is in no wie coagulated, neither can it acquire a due conitency,
even as ometimes is wont to happen to the animal Spirits, being looed from their Fetters, and diipated from the acidity exiting in the blood, wherefore alo uch a blood by divers Practitioners is called putrid.

We commonly ay, becaue it may o happen, that the whole Mas of blood, not as yet equally infected, the laudible part of the blood in the cutting of a Vein, may only flow out, the blood remaining in the body being depraved; the which thing Practitioners daily oberve to happen in Venae-Section; we do not only think with other Practitioners, that the blood remains fluid, without the bodies of thoe who are infected with the Plague; but do alo affirm the like fluidity in the bodies of thoe extinguihed by the Pet, as we have learned by Experience, which perhaps may eem trange to thoe who know not the Nature of volatile Salts, but not o to us, who have very often mingled it with the blood, and the blood always remained fluid, the which cannot be certainly expected from the commixture of any other thing, with the blood, then volatile Salts.

But on the contrary, if you mingle any acid Spirit with the Blood Dictum Factum, the Blood will be more or les Coagulated, according as that Spirit hall be more or les Acid; as for example, if to try the Experiment, we take Oyle of Vitriol, Oyle of Sulphur per Campanum, Aqua Fortis, Aqua Regia, &c. Beides, that the Blood will preently be Coagulated by them, it alo acquires a
Che-Nut Colour. But if we take the Dulcid Spirit of Salt, Juice of Lammons, Ditilled Vinegar or the like, whoe acid Spirit is more Temperate, the Blood will only acquire the Conitency of a groer Syrup, with its red Colour remaining unhurt.

From whence it is evident, the ue of Acids may preerve men from the Plague, not, as according to the Opinion of many Authors, that they cut and attenuate; but as they preerve the natural Conitency of the Blood, and do hinder its being infected, with a more harp Volatile Salt, which we, together with the Air, uck into our Bodies: For this caue, the mot Famous Dr. Sylvius, who likewie hath Contituted the Venom of the Plague, in a more harp Volatile Salt; when, ome Years ince, in the great Plague at Amterdam, which he fore-aw, he took a Crut of Bread, imbrued with white-Wine-Vinegar, in which Mary-Golds had likewie been teeped; by which Alexipharmack he o well preerved himelf, that he never was infected with the Petilential Venome. But when, through too much hat, he omitted the aid Alexipharmack, as oon as he entred into an infected Houe, he was infected with a pain in the Head; from which, at other times, he was free.

Which things being rightly conidered, every one may ee that the Petilent Venome is not indued with any force of Coagulating, as the mot Learned Willis hath tated it, in his Treatie of Feavers, C. 13. But eeing that Dr. Dela-Font
hath ufficiently cleared this to all Oppoers, in his Dicoure concerning the Petilent Venome, Chap. VIII.

We hall not pend any more time, either to the Reader, or our elves, but wave the further Diquiition of thoe things; becaue it is (beides) our purpoe in this Treatie, accurately, to decribe the Petilence: Wherefore we will leave the ret to a further Occaion, eeing it is time that we return to the Incommodities flowing from the more Acid Pancreatick Juyce.

The Pancreatick Juyce, being more harp, is the caue, firt, of every Internal Cold, being firt of all felt in the Region of the Loyns, and afterwards dipered into the whole Body; as for the mot part, we oberve in the beginning of the Fits of Agues, or Intermitting Feavers. Secondly, Of all Cutting paines, as well in the Hypocondria's, and whole Belly, as in other parts of the Body. Thirdly, Of all manifet paines in the Belly, from whence the Sick is ometimes tormented after a wonderful manner. Wherefore we deduce all the black and aeruginous Bile from the ame, more Acid, Pancreatick Juyce: Becaue ometimes being put into a Pewter Chamber Pot, or Bras Baon, they Corrode the ame, and end forth a harp Savour; and alo excite a manifet Effervecency; which every man, who hath aluted but the threhold of Chymitry, knows, cannot happen from any thing but Acids: From whence, they may be compelled to
confes their Errour; who affirm, That all black Choler, proceeding from Vomitting, or Dejection of the Belly, comes from the Follicles of the Gall, or the Spleen.

All thee things are not a little confirmed, by the following Experiment, ometimes made by us in a Dog; in the Section of whom, being alive, having opened the Duodenum, we found a greenih Liquor among the black, uch as the Antients have depicted to us for Atrabilis: that we might purue a more Intimate cognition thereof, we examined diligently all the wayes through which any thing might be tranfer'd to that Intetine; and eeing that beides the Bilar Duct, the Pancreatick, and the Ventrile, there was no way perceptible to the ight, through which any notable Quantity of Humors might be afforded to the Intetines; we judge therefore, that in one of thoe, the matter thereof mut be obcured: Wherefore we examined all thoe wayes; in the firt whereof, we found the Bile, naturally Contituted, that waxing Yellow from a Green: In the econd we found the Pancreatick Juyce mot limpid, like to Ditilled Water: In the third we found the Aliments half crude, having the Colour of White Ahes.

Seeing therefore that neither the Liver, nor the Pancreas, nor alo the Stomach, carryed that Atrabilis to the Intetine, we began to upect whether that Atrabilis might not emerge by the Union of two or three of thoe Humours, being mingled together by coure:
Concerning which thing, that we might attain to a greater Certainty, we affued Spirit of Vitriol to the Bile, drawn forth from its Veicle, and placed it in the heat of the Sun; from whence there was commonly excited from the Black, a Greenih Liquor, uch as we firt found in the Duodenum: Hence we concluded the aid Humour, called Atrabilis, not to flow from this, or that part, but to be generated in the Duodenum. Namely, as the Natural Colour of the Bile hath been tranmitted into Black, and Green, by the Concoure of the more Acid Pancreatick Juyce.

Seeing that the Pancreatick Juyce, by the ordinary Law of Nature, may continually be mingled with the Bile, and the Intetinal Pituity, we will a little propoe the ame, as joyn'd with thoe Humours. If it chanceth that the more luggih Pancreatick Juyce, bounds with a harper Bile, and the Intetinal Pituity rightly Contituted, the trength of the Pancreatick Juyce, in that Concoure, will be altogether infringed; and the Exhalations, which are excited by the Effervecency of thoe Humours, will acend, not o much with Acid, as Lixivious Particles; which, when they reach to the Stomach, by infringing its Fermentation, they will hinder the Concoction of the Aliment, and detroy the Appetite: but if it happen that thoe Exhalations acend to the Jaws, there, amongt other Incommodities, they will induce a Drynes of the Mouth, epecially
if they infect the Spittle with their Salitude: But if they proceed further, through the Milky Veines to the Heart, from whence, with the blood, they may pas through the other parts of the body, they will alo produce a Heat in thoe, as at firt in the Intetines; and there more troubleome, where thoe Exhalations are mot harp.

If a more harp Pancreatick Juyce concurreth with a harper Bile, there will preently be a mighty Effervecency excited in the Duodenum, whereby the Intetines are ometimes o ditended, that they threaten a Ruption; which thing we have very often oberved, whilt we applyed our elves to our Study in Leyden, whilt we mixed together divers Liquors it for Fermentation in two little Veels, in part of the Intetine intercepted by Ligatures, (even as D. Schuyl hath expreed it, Fig. B. in his Treatie, De veteri Medicina) wherefore we judge, in the firt intant Emiion of thoe harp Exhalations which way oever turn'd about, that, that Effervecency will excite very many grievous Incommodities; many whereof will alo preently ceae by the Diipation of thoe Exhalations, becaue either Humour being enervated after that Intetinal Conflict layes down its force, and ceaeth from further contention; for in uch an Effervecency the acid Particles are o joyned with the Saline, that without great difficulty they are never to be eparated; wherefore as unworthy they are expelled from the body for Atra-bilis, if the acid over-grow the Salt, and
get Dominion; in the mean time, they mot mierably afflict the body, no otherwie than as Hotile Souldiers, the place through which they pas, by Eroding, and Ulcerating, &c. From whence Fluxes of the belly, Vomitings, Tenemus, Dyenteries, and ix Hundred other Incommodities pringing from the Atra-bilis will proceed, and thoe the more grievous, or more gentle, as the acidity of the Pancreatick juyce hall remain more or les, intemperate after the aid Conflict.

If beides the Bile, and the Pancreatick juyce offending even now poken of, much Phlegme ticks in the Gutts, and if the ame phlegme be vicous, by reaon of the Incommodities already declared, there will happen Flatulencies, the force and energy of which, whereby they are obnoxious to men, he that deireth to be informed, let him read J. Fiennus, and others, who have profeedly Written of Flatulencies.

If a harper Pancreatick Juyce concurs with a more luggih Bile, it will not excite o manifet an Effervecency, but by its Acrimony will tir up wringings of the Gutts, Eroions, &c. but if being more intemperate, paing through the little Channels of the Lactean Veins, it toucheth the firt and lat reidence of life, it will produce the Auxiety of the Heart, Syncope, and many other Incommodities hereafter recited, whoe ymptoms will be of larger continuance than thoe which we have deemed to arie from Exhalations, and from thence a greater
Intemperance of the Pancreatick Juyce may be feared, when the Bile, wherewith it is wont to be attempred, is luggih and inipid, as the mot learned Glion, amongt other things writeth, that he hath oberved in his Anatomy of the Liver, at the end of the 39. Chapter, where he aith: There was with us a Woman Cachectick, in whoe Biliar Veicle we found a erous Humour a little pale, little bitter, or rather inipid, but next to a weetnes.

The like to which we have alo oberved in the Icterick, or thoe Afflicted with the Jaundies, in the Year 1664. being Diected by the famous Sylvius, in the Hopital of Leyden, whoe Bile, whilt we more accurately examined, in the Houe of D. Elner, in the preence of D. Kohnius, we found it plainly erous, and o little indued with a Yellow colour, that a Linnen Rag being put into it, would carcely be tinged with any Yellownes, and to the Tongue exhibited little or nothing of Amaritude.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The Dieaes proceeding from a vitiated Pancreatick Juyce.
div.p: EVen as from the Vitiation of the Pancreatick Juyce, we have hewed that divers Functions are hurt; o from the ame Fountain do we judge that various Effects may be derived: Amongt which we hall deervedly aigne the firt and chiefet place to all Agues, and intermitting Feavours, becaue we judge the Accees thereof to be acribed to the Pancreatick Juyce, being tagnant in one or more of the lateral Ducts, by reaon of an Obtruction made by Phlegme, and by reaon of the force of the Acrimony increaed, one while ooner, another while later, prepareth a paage for it elf through the obtructing Pituity, then cauing a vicious Effervecency in the Duodenum, and being tranlated to the Heart, produceth a preternatural pule.

Which Opinion, eeing that hitherto it hath been known to few, to avoid confuion in the end of this little Book, we have et a part an entire Chapter, wherein we will treat of intermitting Feavers, to which we end the Reader, whilt in the mean time, we go forward to the other
Dieaes, pringing from this more intemperate juyce.

It eems probable to us, that the caue of the Arthritis (or Gout) derives its original from the aid acid Pancreatick Juyce; namely, when its elevated acidity, either with Phlegme, or the Serum of the blood is carried to the joynts, and lyeth in them; the ymptoms alo concurring, eems to perwade the ame thing to us; for thoe pains for the mot part are wont both to invade, and be exaperated with a Paroxyme of a Feaver, but according to the divere manner, wherewith the Bile and the intetinal Pituity are affected; o thoe paines of the Joynts do alo manifet themelves after a divere Mode, with the ret of the concomitant Symptoms.

The ame thing is tetified by the Urine, which once for curioity ake, we tated with Doctor Rooendael, in which we found a notable Acidity. We have alo oberved (which eems not a little to confirm this our Opinion) in thee Regions, that Wine, epecially Renih, is exceedingly advere to thoe who are obnoxious to this Ditemper; the which we judge to happen from the ame, becaue that Wine contains in it a greater acidity than other Wines.

That this more acid Pancreatick Juyce doth increae Hunger, and tir up and inatiable, and Dog-like Appetite; few hereafter will doubt, who have conidered diligently, that the Pancreatick Juyce, and the harp Exhalations
thereof do acend even into the Stomach, as is manifet by the Sower Belchings, violently breaking forth, and ometimes by the Vomiting forth of Humours, more or les acid.

If they ay that that juyce which is effued into the Intetine, the breadth of four Fingers below the Pylorus, cannot acend through the Pylorus into the Stomach, it being naturally hut; we may alo ask how the Bile (which by all is granted) may acend to the Stomach, which iueth into the Intetine by the ame paage: If they ay it comes to pas by the in verted peritaltick Motion of the Intetines, we then ay, that by the ame Motion, the Pancreatick Juyce may alo acend, to which we hall adde that Exhalations do far more eaily acend into the Stomach than the Humours.

More acid Exhalations being excited, from the Pancreatick Juyce, through its Effervecency, and altogether with Flatulencies, carryed through the Venae Lactae to the Heart, and from thence to the Lungs, and there ticking, do not only caue a difficult Repiration, but alo a dry Cough; the Confirmation of which, we have not only een in the Hopital of Leyden, but ele-where: For, in the diffecting of Dead Bodies, we have often found the Parenchyma of the Lungs, and its Veels, as yet ditended with Wind. If a Vicid Pituity accompanies thoe Windy Exhalations, and be detained in the Lungs, what doth it then produce
but the Species of an Athma? But if thoe Exhalations, and Flatulencies, do tend further to the Head, the paines thereof will produce Alienation of the Mind, and ometimes infinite other Dicommodities; every man may believe, That the Epileptick Invaions of Children, which they call Stuypiens, i. e. the Dutch.
doth proceed from the aid, more Acid, Pancreatick Juyce, who hath accurately attended to thoe Invaions, and the Symptomes accompanying them, and the way of Cure: For, beides that Acidity, which doth very often breath through the Mouth, they uffer the Gripings of the Belly; the Milk may likewie be perceived to be concreted, both upwards, and downwards; the Excrements of the belly are more Green, and give forth a harp Odour: they are alo cured by the tempering of Acidity: as for Example, with Aqua Feniculi, Aqua Lillioru¯ Conuallium, Spir. Salis Armoniaci, &c.

The ame, more Acid, Pancratick Juyce, carryed to the blood, through the Lactean Veines, will give it a greater Conitency; whence the Blood, les Rarifying, will produce a leer Pule: From which, Vice highly exceeding, we judge a Syncope, ometimes to be produced, which is not a little confirmed by that Example which Lazarus Riverius relates in Lib. VIII. Fol. 358. of his Practice concerning that Syncope, which P. Salius, as he reports, Lib. De Afect. Practic. Cap. IV. oberved in a Girle
of 14 Years of Age: Who, after a dayes uffering of Heavines of the Head, Vertigo, and grievous Anxieties, the day following uddainly dyed: Afterwards her Body being diffected, the whole blood in the great Artery and the Vena Cava appeared to be Concreted, and o changed that it might intirely be drawn out from the Vein, and Artery, even as a Sword out of its Scabbard.

Concerning which thing, if any doubt, either by ours, or others Examples, let him take an acid Liquor, and pour it, by degrees, into the Vein of any Living Dog, and he hall not only oberve the Blood, therein, to be o Coagulated, and Concreted, that the greater bloody Veels may be tranverly cut, without the Effuion of the blood; but alo when the acid Liquor hall come, in a notable Quantity, to the right Ventricle of the Heart, that it will preently extinguih, and kill the Dog. Alo, no man will deny, that Convulions, for the mot part, proceed from an Internal Caue, from the Acrimony of Humours, irritating the Nerves, and cauing, by a greater Influx of the animal Spirits, into the Mucles, Involuntary, and alo Violent Motions: But when there is a two fold Acrimony of Humours, viz. Acid, and Salt, ome perhaps may doubt, which of thee do mot frequently produce thoe Convulive Motions: But, for as much as we can oberve, they rather proceed from an acid Acrimony, than a Salt: becaue we ee that Aromatick Medicaments, and thoe abounding
with a Volatile Salt, do very much conduce to their Cure; which would never come to pas, if they drew their Original from a Saline Acrimony. Beides, they are accompanyed with uch Symptomes, which are wont to be the Concomitants of Dieaes, ariing from an acid Acrimony: Yea, the Effects of Acids are allowed to be far more powerful, as is to be een in Helmont De Lithiai. Cap. 9. Pag. 725. §. 71. where he relates, that he aw a Chymit, which, after he had been much Converant about making of Aqua Regia, he fell into the Palpitation of the Heart, Convulions, and many other Incredible Dolours, by reaon of the acid Exhalations, which mingled themelves with his Blood. From the ame Acidity we tedfatly believe, That the Strangury is very often produced, eeing that, together with other Students, we have ometimes found the Urines of uch as have laboured under the Strangury, in the Hopital of Leyden, to be Acid; and alo een the ame Perons cured with uch Medicines, as temper Acidity.

The which if you are minded to try, aith Helmont, De Pleura Furente §. 14. Whether or no the Strangury may not proceed from Acidity, mix ome Drops at leat of harp Wine, with the rine, lately ent forth without pain, and inject it again by a Syringe, and you hall find, to your Pain, that what I ay, is true. Alo, that from the more acid Pancreatick Juyce, Ulcers do ometimes break forth in the Skin, corroding the
ame, as alo producing very great paines, they will not deny, who, following the Opinions of the Antients, determine them to arie from the Atra-Bilis; eeing that the Atra-Bilis of the Antients (as we have above Demontrated) hath its Original from the more acid Pancreatick Juyce.
We are like-wie plainly perwaded, that the more acid Pancreatick Juyce, epecially if it hath any Auterity conjoyned with it, produceth a greater atringency of the Belly.

For, if the Bile, by its Acrimony irritating the Guts (as is granted) may excite the Flux of the Belly, why may not that, which is contrary to uch a Bile, produce a contrary Effect? Notwithtanding, if the belly be bound by a Vicid Matter, then we think, likewie, that a Flux may happen from the harper Pancreatick Juyce, as it hath a power of inciding, and attenuating, the Vicid Pituity: From which it is manifet, that the Pancreatick Juyce, according to the Diverity of Humours, concurring with it, doth very often produce a divere and contrary Effect; which thing we would have well noted, let we hould eem to contradict our elf, in explicating the Effects of this juyce.

As yet we think, even as we eem to have already aid, that the Atra and Eruginous Bile is excited from the more acid Pancreatick Juyce, and a certain harp Bile concurring; and conequently all Dieaes, which Authors
deduce from them; and therefore they are not cured by other Medicaments, than thoe which are fit to correct the more acid Pancreatick Juyce: Which, as it is Cononant with Reaon; o it will not appear Incredible to thoe, who will conider the things above poken by us, with a more attentive Mind.

But perhaps ome will ay, after what manner doth the Pancreatick Juyce produce the Atra-Bilis, eeing that we have acribed the Whitihnes of the Chyle, after the Effervecency, in the thin Gut, to the acidity of the Pancreatick Juyce? To which we anwer, That Acids, according to the Diverity of the matter where-with they are mixed, do alo produce a divers Colour; for example, pour an acid Spirit to common Sulphur, diolved in a Lixivium, and its red Colour will be changed into white. Antimony Calcind, with Nitre or Chalk, being boyl'd in Fountain-Water, and any acid thing, being affued to its clear Colature, will preently acquire a Saffron Colour.

A clear Infuion of Galls, mixed with the Solution of Vitriol, maketh Ink, to which, if you add the acid Spirit of Vitriol, that Ink will loe all its blacknes, and become clear, like to Fountain-Water. The Blew Tincture of Violets, being mixed with Oyle of Vitriol, will wax into a Purple. The Wood Acanthus brought from Braile, being infued in Common Water, doth freely yeild a red Tincture,
which put to Ditilled Vinegar, acquires a Colour like to White-Wine. A Knife, after it, hath cut a Pomecitron, in the Middle, unles it be wiped, and cleaned, from the Soure Juyce of the Citron, in a hort time will be reduced to a nigrous Colour. And why from the ame acidity too much exalted in Ulcers, the Cyrurgions Probe may not be tained with a certain Blacknes, (as we have very often oberved) and uch Ulcers be happily cured by Temperating of the acidity, (as Helmont admoniheth De Blae humano, §. 53. we leave to the judgment of others?

It may here uffice for us to have proved, that from one and the ame acid, permixed with divere things; one while a White, another a Black, another a Yellow, another a Purple, and o moreover other Colours may arie. He which deireth to excite many Colours in the Solution of Minerals and Vegitables endued with no Colour, let him go to that mot curious Treatie which D.
