Willis hath written, concerning Fermentation, where pag. 88. Edit. Ang. he may find very many Mutations of Colours not unprofitable; and being about to aigne the Reaon thereof, he aith in the following page: If the reaon of this Phaeno-mena be enquired, it ought altogether to be deduced from thoe minute particles within the pores of every contained Liquor; which according to the cituation and poition, being after a divers manner altered by the Infuion of another Liquor, do diverly tranmit the beams of the light, and manifoldly break, or
reflect it, and o caue the divers appearances of Colours, &c.

Having now unfolded the Dieaes rien from the more acid Pancreatick Juyce, we eem in our elves to hear ome in hort to ask the Quetion, from whence the acid Humour in the body may proceed, if we do not ue any acid things? To which we anwer, that we can in no wie want thoe things which abound with an acidity. For there is an acidity in the air, which appeareth, if the Caput Mortuum of Vitriol be expoed to the air, which from the ame eliciteth a new acidity. Alo, that the air is full of Nitrous particles, Gaendus, Entius, Digbaeus, and others, which profeedly, or otherwie ingeniouly treat of this Matter, have proved: But no man is ignorant, that Nitre containeth in it elf an acidity. There is alo an acidity inherent in Aliments: For in Kitchings, if fleh, or other Aliments, begin to corrupt, their Broth doth wax ower; yea, we have collected an acid Spirit in quantity ufficiently large, from the weetet of Condiments, to wit, Sugar, by chymical Art.

There is alo an acidity inherent in Drink; for Beer, or Ale, as alo Wine, being left to themelves, without the addition of any other thing, do wax Soure: From whence, it is no wonder, as Hippocrates witneeth, Lib. De Vet. Med. Text. 24 that there hould be an Acidity in Men. But, it being granted, that there is an acid Humour in our Bodies, ome one, more deirous of Truth, may ask, How it
comes to pas, that it doth not only corrode the parts of our Bodies, but alo Copper, and Tinn, as we have hewed above? To this we hall alo anwer, That the Fermentations, continually happening in our Bodies, is ufficicient for this thing: For, we daily ee that by their help, many things are very harp, which before were weet, or at leat Temperate: VVhether now this may happen by the Diipation of the animal Spirits, or by reaon of any other inward Caue, we leave to the Judgment of others. Likewie, Experience tetifies, that Men, feeding upon a cold Diet, do ometimes, for the ame Reaon, and Caue, fall into burning Feavers.

We have alo deervedly acribed the Uterine Suffocation, or Mother-fits, o called, to the Pancreatick juyce divers ways vitiated, but epecially the Autere: The following Obervation eems to give us no mall light into the Truth of this Matter, which our Friend Elnerus, in the Year 1667. ent to us from Paris to Andegave: We opened (aith he) a Maid, extinguihed by the Suffocation of the Womb, in whoe dead body we found nothing at all, to which death might be acribed, but the blood coagulated in the Ventricles of the Heart, beyond the order of Nature. Which too much coagulation of the blood may not be deduced from any other caue, than from an acid Juyce, as we have ufficiently proved.

But the reaon why we judge that this Effect is not produced by the Pancreatick Juyce, being
imply acid, is, that all women which have a harp Pancreatick Juyce, are not affected with that Dieae: And therefore we do the more eaily believe, that there is an auterity, or harh Sowernes preent with it; becaue we have known almot the like Dieae excited from the Pancreatick Juyce, being autere, in a certain Bitch, as alo in a Famous Man, the truth of which the following Tetimony freely exhibiteth to us; done in the Year 1663. as it was communicated to me by the mot expert Dr. Sylvius: I teted the Pancreatick Juyce, and found it (firt) as it were Saltih; but afterward, the Relih being ome-what changed, it eemed then to be Sub-acid, with a light Auterity; There was uch a Stink produced in my Mouth, that two of my Acquaintance, which were with us, admonihed me concerning it: The Stink was like to that which rieth from Muddy, and trinking Water. My Mouth, and Jaws, were not only exiccated, or dried, but alo o contringed, that I eemed to be uffoccated; which like thing, I uffer by a Dieae familiar to me: And all thee things vanihed not uddainly, but remained, and endured for a while, till they left me by Degrees, and of their own Accord.

The Bitch's Juyce was brought to the Famous Dr. Sylvius, and exhibited to his Tat, in our preence. From this, and the like Obervations, it eemeth not aburd to aert, That Men may ome-time be affected with a like Hyterick Suffocation; epecially, when
its nearet Caue happens, not from the VVomb, but from the mall Gut; in which, by reaon of the Vitious Effervecency of concurring Humours excited, Exhalations, and autere Flatulencies are tirred up; which, as often as they arie through the Oeephagus, or Gullet, and come to the Arteria-Aperia, or Wind-Pipe, they o contringe thoe parts, that the Sick think themelves to be in the peril of Strangulation, or Choaking.

That divers Species of the Hypocondriack Affection may be produced by the aid Pancreatick juyce divers ways vitiated, the Books of Practical Phyitians do tetifie, and the ymptoms confirme. But that we tay no longer upon the more acid, and autere Pancreatick juyce, and the effects from them ariing; we think fit to deduce at leat one effect from the aid juyce more Salt, imagine a erous Diarrhaea, which by its aline Acrimony, produceth a more violent, and more frequent peritaltick Motion of the Gutts.

Thee things being rightly conidered, we doubt not but that by a diligent tract of time, by the Obervation of thoe who happen to be converant about the Sick, many effects will be made more manifet: And if there be more of Art in knowing than in curing Dieaes, who ees not that this Pancreatick juyce being altogether known, the cure of many Dieaes may be performed more eaily, more peedily, and
more profitably. Firt of all in this Treatie, we have decribed the Dieaes taking their Original from a more acid Pancreatick juyce, becaue they more often occur, and produce greater trouble, than thoe which derive their Original from this juyce by any other way vitiated, for the acid Humour excelling the ret, Witnes Hippoc. lib. de Vet. Med. Text. 42. 14. of all others is the mot Incommodious.

div.head: CHAP. X. How the vitiated Pancreatick Juyce may be Corrected.
div.p: SEeing that it is not ufficient to have aid in what manner the Pancreatick Juyce may offend, Namely, by exerciing too great an Acidity, Salitude, and Amaritude; we have not retored it, aith Hyppocrates, before that the ame be purged, and overthrown by the admixing of other things, Lib. de vet. Med. Text 34.
But with what Medicaments the Vices of the Pancreatick Juyce, above declared, may more eaily be tempered, or evacuated we hall now handle in brief.

The more paring Separation, or Excretion, of the Pancreatick Juyce, happening by reaon of Vicidity, will be cured by Medicines, correcting any Vicidity; uch are Volatile Acids, as alo Salts, as well Volatile as Fixt; epecially the Volatile Salt of Amber eems to agree with our buines; which, beides the Volatile Salt, alo containes certain Acid Particles: But, as often as the Pancreatick Juyce is thought to be les acid, then ue pure Acids, on the contrary, as often as the Acidity thereof exceeds, then Salts are mot conducible.
When the Excretion of the Pancreatick Juyce is more paring, by reaon of an Obtruction happening in one or more of the Lateral Ducts, the Medicines, but now poken of, are alo profitable; for, except they looen, cleane, and cat forth the Obtructing Pituity, or Remedy the Vicous Crudity of the Blood, they will certainly profit nothing, as we hall endeavour, more largely, to explain the ame in the ubequent Chapter, when we hall treat of intermitting Feavers.

The more Copious Increae of the Pancreatick Juyce, will be Cured, as well by abtaining from much Drink, epecially uch as is harp; alo by uing uch Medicaments as may expel it from the body by the belly; as alo Sweats, and Urines. But, among uch Medicaments, as educe it by the Belly, uch as Purge-Water, are convenient above others; by help whereof, the Serous Humours are purged, more than the Bilious: which, ome years ince, we have oberved in not a few Dogs, to whom we exhibited, as well Hydragogues as Cholagues; and, eeing that they excellently deponed the belly, we uddenly opened the Abdomen, at the very time of purgation; the Dog's as yet living; which done, we could oberve, although difficulty, in thoe to whom we had given a Cholagogue, viz. one Dram of Diagredium, that the Bile did flow in a far greater Quantity, from the Intetinal biliar Duct; but in another, to whom we had exhibited a Hydragogue, namely, of Powder
of Jallap two Drams, we oberved that the Pancreatick Juyce did break forth in a large Quantity, from its Ductus into the Intetines, although then the Bile alo did iue forth in a great Quantity; and in another, to whom we had given a Cholagogue, the Pancreatick Juyce did alo flow forth in a greater Quantity, than uuall; nevertheles we are able to collect, that the Bile is far more Copiouly purged by Cholagogues, and the Pancreatick Juyce by Hydragogues.

In thee Experiments, performed other things, did yet occur, worthy of note; for firt of all, at the very time of purgation, there was nothing depoited through the Meeraick Arteries into the Cavity of the Intetines; but what o ever of a Liquid matter remained in them, after expreion, was ucked up by the Venae Lacteae, or Meeraick Veines. Secondly, That thoe Ducts, in whom the Lactean Veines appeared not: After 3. or 4. Hours Exhibition of Aliment, we cut the Abdomen in them; neither the Bile, nor the Pancreatick Juyce, was carryed to the Intetine, in a more than uual Quantity. Concerning which, eeing that other things, as yet remain to be poken to, we hall defer it to another occaion, untill by many Experiments, more urely made, we hall more perfectly (alo) undertand the force of other Medicaments. The Pancreatick Juyce, over Fluid, will be corrected by the prudent aumption of Vicid Aliments; uch are Pills of Hound's
Tongue, and other things which incraate.

In reference to the Qualities of the Pancreatick Juyce, perceptible to the tat, if it offends by too much Acidity, Auterity, or Sality, it will be cured, Firt, With altering Medicines, as Hippocrates hath rightly taught us, De Vet. Med. Tex. 31. 20. where he aith: And I perceive all other Fluxes, which happen by reaon of the Acrimony, and Intemperances of Humours, are retored by their tempering and Cocting. But that will eaily be abolved by the Adminitration of the Medicines, even now poken of.
The more Acid Pancreatick Juyce will be cured, Firt, With a pure Volatile Salt, as an Aromatick, by tempering the ame.
Secondly, It will be cured with a Lixivious Salt, as well fixed as Volatile, by infringing its Power.
Thirdly, It will be cured by Crabs Eyes, Coralls, Chalk, Shells, epecially being Calcined, fileings of Steel, and the like, by concentrating it.

Fourthly, It will be cured, by Oleous Emulions, as alo, by divere Oyles, made as well by expreion, as Ditillation, as it were Wrapping about it, and Blunting the Edge thereof. [I know not how to render Obvoluo and Obtundo better].

Fifthly. It will be cured with water, & watery things, wahing and weakning it. But here no Purges are to be exhibited; becaue, hitherto,
none are known; which, without great difficulty, do educe the Acid Humours, not tempered; o that, Aphorime of Hippoc. 22. Sect. 11. which aith, Things cocted not crude, being brought forth by a Purging Medicine, are not crude in their beginning, unles they well: But many do not well; doth rightly here take place. The autere Pancreatick Juyce will be cured by Volatile Salts, as firt, by the Ditilled Spirit of Salt Ammoniac, after the addition of Salt of Tartar, and Water; to which alo, may be referred Cator, and its Tincture.

The Salt Pancreatick Juyce, and a Diarhaea, from thence ariing, may be cured by the Diacordium of Fracatorius, Pills of Hound's Tongue, Coralls, burnt Hart's-horn, Bezoar-Stone, and other things Incraating, and alo Concentrating Salitude.

div.head: CHAP. XI. The Hitory of Agues, or Intermitting Feavers.
div.p: BEcaue we have before promied, in the Nineth Chapter, that we would, in this place, demontrate, that Intermitting Feavers have their Original from the Preternatural Dipoition of the aid Pancreatick Juyce, we cannot but annex their Hitory; not becaue, the difficulty of Explicating thee Feavers, is obcure to us, nor hunneth none of the mot Expert Phyitians; So as, hither-to, they have not atisfied the Curious in their Explications: So that, being by mot paed over with a dry Foot, they have left behind them a Series of innumerable Difficulties; but, becaue we judge it to be a thing of o great moment, that as many as hither-to have given themelves to the earch of Intermitting Feavers, have till deired to this Labour, the further Indutry of other Learned Men: For, very many Dieaes do every day occur in our Practice, wherein that Feaver either proceedeth, is concomitant, or doth follow; So that, ometimes it requireth an intire Method of Curation, for it elf.

Which, eeing it is o, we think our Cogitations, and Experiments, not to be ingrateful to the Curious Searchers of Nature, epecially if we hold their minds not long in upence, by rehearing the Sentenes and Opinions of many Authors, as they ordinarily have done, who have gone before us, in the ame kind of Study: or retain thoe things, by hewing an intire Series of Quetions, relating more to Curioity, than to the neceity of the thing to be known; but we hall preently expound, in a few words, as much as is poible, thoe things which we judge concerning this matter.

Seeing that Aritotle hath rightly aid, Lib. 2. Phyic. Cap. 13. That there can be a ure Knowledge of nothing, the Caue, or Original whereof, is not known: We, contrary to the Common Order, hall endeavour to purue the Nature of Intermitting Feavers, by earching out their Signes and Caues.

Seeing that all Phyitians, which have hither-to written of Intermitting Feavers, cry out that their Pathognomick Signe is a more Frequent, and Preternatural Pule; to know the Nature, altogether of Intermitting Feavers, by earching into the Caues of the Pule, we judge with the never ufficiently praied Fran. de le Boe-Sylvius, that the Caue of a more Preternatural Pule, is either (firt) the too much, and Permanent Rare-faction of the Blood, ariing from a more Potent Fire, breaking forth from the Effervecency of both
Bloods. Or, Secondly, becaue of any harpnes, being at one time Acid, at another Lixivious, another while brinihly Salt, driven through the Veines, with the Blood, to the Heart, and Internally gnawing the Parenchyma of the Heart. Or, Thirdly, omething halituouly Flatulent, and like-wie carried with the Blood to the Heart, or excited, by the Effervecency, in the Heart; and increaing the Explication of the Ventricles of the Heart. Or, Fourthly, omething harp, or hard, either in the Peri-cardium, or ele-where exiting, and externally gnawing, or pricking the Heart.

Thee few things being premied, there is none but may ee, that the caue of continuall Feavers, is continually carryed to the Heart, but the caue of Intermittents by Intervals. It is not our purpoe here to peak of Continual Feavers, thoe that are deirous of earching out, and knowing of the Nature of thoe, we recommend them to the Practice of Dr. Sylvius, where, amongt other things, accurately delivered, they may find the exact Decription of thoe Feavers, Chap. 29. Pag. 407. And we, in the mean-time, being about to deliver the Decription of Intermitting Feavers, hall ay, That uch a Focus, or Minera, of Intermitting Feavers, is required, which is apt to tranmit the caue of a more frequent, and Preternatural Pule, by Intervals, to the Heart.

Sundry men have ought this Minera, in divere parts of the Body; ome have immagined they have found it in the Mas of Blood, which, to ome others eemed les true, to whom the Continual Motion of the Blood, was known; becaue the Circulation of the Blood is performed once, twice, or four times a day: For, the mot accurate Dr. Lower, in his Treatife of the Heart, Fol. 156. proveth, That the Blood of a Man, well dipoed, circulateth through the Heart, in the pace of one Hour, thirty times: But being granted, (which in no wie, may be denyed) that the Mas of Blood, of the whole body at leat, ometimes in a Day, doth flow back to the Heart; part of which, if evilly affected, as often as it traniteth the Heart, would produce a Fit of a Feaver; and o, from the Blood naturally following, neither a Tertian, or a Quartan Feaver may be deduced, unles they ay that the Blood doth abolve this Tragedy, being preternaturally detained in any part of the body; which like-wie, doth not alike appear to thoe, to whom it is known, how eaily the Volatile Spirits exhale, by the Detention of the blood, and the remaining Particles of the blood being made more harp, do uddenly excite, mutually, among themelves, a Heat and Inflamation of the Part; to which, if an Apoteme be ubjoyned that will affect the Blood, paing through its Circuits continually, and not by Intervals: Whence if a Feaver follows, it ought not to be called
an Intermitting, but a Continuall Feaver.

If they ay that the obtruction is not expected to the generation of intermitting Feavers, but to furnih the phlegme which is of that nature that daily, the yellow Bile wch. every third day, and the Atra-bile which every fourth day may produce a certain ebullition: many of a higher ingenuity, may ask firt whether or no thoe humours uch as they are decribed in the Schools can be Demontrated to be in the mas of Blood, eeing it is evident by what is already aid the Atrabilis derives its original from the yellow Bile, and more acid pancreatick Juyce. Secondly, how doth that eem probable that a humour more cold, tenatious, and unapt for motion, as phlegme, daily, and a hot humour being more fluid and being fit for motion as yellow Choler, hould every other day onely excite a feaverih Ebullition in the Blood; Thirdly, how intermitting Feavers may be changed from quotidians into tertrans, quartans, and the contrary. Fourthly, to what humours they can acribe Quintans, extans, or thoe which have more eldome periods (of which Fernelius lib. 4. cap. 14.) if they determine that each Feavour draws its Original from a certain peculiar Humour.

But they which have held the minera of intermitting Feavers to be latent in ome part of the Body, have mot of them ought it in the Abdomen; for nauceounes, loathing of Food, Torments, Colds, Horrors, Rigors, and other
preludiums of the fits conpicuous to none but uch as are more attentively dipoed, do hew the Abdomen to be evilly habited. A vomiting excited either by Nature or Art, and very often, preently awageing the fiercenes of the fits, heweth the principal ways or paages thereof to be evilly habited. The Cure it elf of the Abdomen alo in the beginning of the acces declareth the ame according to Fernelius de ede intermittentium lib. 4. cap. 10. for Fomentations applied to the Hypocondriaes procure a remiion of horror, rigor, and other Symptomes.

But what part of the Abdomen in thee Feavers is evilly affected, hath wearied the brains of many; for o confuedly have they ought their minera, that nothing of certainty can be concluded from their writings or opinions; for ome have ought it in the meeraick Veines, ome in the Branches of the vena porta between the Liver and the Spleen, ome in other Veels, yea alo in the great Colon, the duplicature of the Omentum which is under the ventricle, and in innumerable other things have they determined the focus of intermitting Feavours, whoe Clouds of fality in thee our more happy times the un of Truth hath o dicued and diipated, that they want not our improvement. Therefore leat we conume our own, and the Readers time, by writing more things obvious as well in the Books of the Ancients as in the Moderns, we hall willingly pas them by: Seeing that the caue of all intermitting
Feavours eemes to us to be contained in the pancreas alone.

The reaon of this Opinion is this, that having conidered the parts of the whole Body of man, which by intervals only may tranmit the Caue of thee Feavers to the heart, none can be found in the whole body to which not only the Focus of intermitting Feavers, but alo the caues of all their ymptomes may be imputed beides the Pancreas.

But ome perhaps may ay, that heat, thirt, ulcers, breaking forth in the lips of the Feaverih, bitter Vomitings, Cholerick Excrements, and other ymtomes wont to accompany tertain Feavers do declare the bile to be primarily offended, wherefore the Caue of all intermitting Feavers ought not to be acribed to the pancreas alone.

But truly this objection will fall of its own accord, thoe things being known which we hall peak of in the following Dicoure concerning the Reaons of divers Symptomes; for we know that in tertians the bile is very often predominant, but it is to be noted that its abundance doth not caue an intermitting Feaver; becaue that is perceived after it hath excited a vitious Efferveency by intervals with the pancreatick Juice, in which if the bile gets Dominion, the igns thereof even now declared do omtimes manifet themelves; but becaue this Effervecency proceeds from the pancreatick Juice preternaturally dipoed, that Feaver is not acribed to the Bile, but to the Pancreatick
Juyce, as, by the Sequel, hall more plainly appear. We judge the caue of Intermitting Feavers to be an Obtruction, made in one or more of the Lateral Ducts; becaue of Pituity, carryed thither in too large a quantity, and there detained: VVhich thing eems to us to happen for the following Reaon; to wit, For as much, as the Pituity, of the thin Guts, epecially that ticking to the ides, let they hould be hurt by the abounding Humours, being in too great a quantity, by reaon of the immoderate Exercies of the Body, and perhaps by an over-much ue of hot Aliments, or by ome Error, committed in the ix Non-Naturals, is diolved, and with other Humours, carryed to the Heart, by the Milky Veines: From whence, by the Order of Circulation, this Phlegmatick Matter, together with the ret of the Blood, is driven to the Pancreas; and being eparated in its Glandules, with the Pancreatick Juyce, it enters the Lateral Ducts of the Pancreas; in which, either by the External Cold, or of that Bowel it concreteth, and is Coagulated; by which reaon, it obtructeth either one or more of the Laterall Ducts.

VVe think the accees of intermitting Feavers, ought to be acribed to the Pancreatick Juyce, tagnant in one or more of the Lateral Ducts, by reaon of an Obtruction; and one while ooner, another while later, preparing a way for it elf, through the Obtructing Phlegme, by its Acrimony increaed; and not
only cauing a Vitious Effervecency in the mall Gut; but being every way carryed, epecially to the Heart, produceth a more frequent, and preternatural Pule.
Which, that it may more clearly appear, we hall pend a little time in the unfolding thereof.

That Coagulation, which we have mentioned to happen in the Pancreatick Juyce, we have ome-time oberved in a Dog, whoe Juyce we endeavoured to collect in the Winter time; which, by the cold of the Ambient Air, was o thickned, that only a little would flow forth, and of a gros Conitency, untill the Dog, being placed before the Fire, between two Pillows began to grow hot; from whence the Pancreatick Juyce did flow more Fluid, and more Copiouly. We have oberved, that the Coagulation of the Pancreatick Juyce hath excited Obtructions, in the Lateral Ducts, of the Pancreas, as in the Year 1663, with the Famous Dr. Sylvius, in a certain Woman, labouring under an intermitting Feaver, into whoe Ductus Pancreaticus, after Death, we injected, by a Syringe, a very Volatile blewih Liquor; which, out of the great Duct, into which it was cat, did penetrate into mot of the Lateral Ducts, whilt in a few, although more near to the Intetinal great Duct, by reaon of an Obtruction, it was topped: From whence, by the aid Colour, the Subtance of the Pancreas it elf, was tinged in one place, and not in another.

The Pancreatick Juyce, being tagnant in one or more of the Lateral Ducts, by reaon of an Obtruction, by its delay becometh more harp, and at length, perforating the Obtructing Phlegme, prepareth it elf a paage, through the Obtruction, into the common or middle Duct, until all the detained Juyce, being effued, the Phlegme as yet adhereing to the ides of the Duct, grows together again, and by its mutual Reunion, renews the Obtruction: Whence at length, the Pancreatick Juyce is Collected for the following Fit; which again, by its delay, being made more harp, doth again perforate the Obtructing Pituity, and produceth a new Paroxyme; which Fits, return alwayes at the ame time, as often as the Pituity, cauing the Obtruction, doth occur, in the ame Quantity, and Vicidity, with the Pancreatick Juyce, of the ame Acidity, and Acrimony.

The Pancreatick Juyce is made more harp by Stagnation, in as much, as the Animal Spirits do not o traightly embrace it, but leave it obtructing: Hence therefore, by the diipated Spirits, wont to attemper it, there redounds a greater Acidity of the Pancreatick Juyce. Would you have a Simillitude? We will grant it: New Ale, included in Hogsheads, Whether or no, by a certain delay, it doth not loe its Sweetnes? Conider, that all Wine turns to Vinegar, the Spirits being diipated; alo that Vinegar it elf, by delay, is made more harp.

For, every heat, diipating the Animal Spirits, caueth every harp thing to be more harp: So that, it ought to eem trange to none, if we ay, that the Pancreatick Juyce, by tagnation, deerteth its genuine Dipoition, and paeth into a more acid Acrimony. But the Pancreatick Juyce, being made more harp by tagnation, and effued into the thin Gut, with the Flegmme and Bile, tirs up a vitious Effervecency; and indeed, by reaon of uch a Pancreatick Juyce, tretchings, yawnings, and horrors are produced, and every-where a ence of Cold, epecially in the Region of the Loynes, in which the Fit begins. Neither is that firt called a Feaver, which either the Pancreatick Juyce, it elf, vitiouly Effervecing in the mall Gut; or at leat, Exhalations from thence ariing, and at length, carryed to the right Ventricle of the Heart; and, after a certain manner, irritating it to a more frequent Contraction of it elf. But we judge that the Pancreatick Juyce, by its acid Acrimony, performs this thing; although nothing hinders, but that omething of a Saline Acrimony, ariing from the Bile may concur: becaue we daily oberve, that Exhalations do acend in the Effervecency, between Acids and Salts; which, being moved to the Noe, by its Acrimony, caueth Offence. Intermitting Feavers by the reaon already given, proceeding from the Pancreatick Juyce, are divided into Simple, and Compound; the Simple, by reaon of their Fits, returning at divers times, are ditinguihed
into Quotidians which daily, Tertians which every other day, & Quartans which on the fourth day, Quintans which on the fifth, &c. do return.

Thoe are called Compound which excite divers fits in one and the ame ick peron, and they are either of the ame Species: as double quotidians, double or treble tertians, double or treble quartans, &c. Or they are of a divers Species, as a Quotidian with a Tertian, a Tertian with a Quartan, &c. We hall ay nothing in this place concerning thoe Feavers which are compounded of intermittents and continual, tho we know they are daily to be oberved by practitioners; for he which hath known & inpected the Nature of intermitting and continual Feavers, may conider that this complication carryes nothing of difficulty to our Opinion, which is clearer than the Meridian Light. They are alo ditinguihed by reaon of an urgent cold, and heat into cold, and burning Feavers; although for the mot part the cold is wont to go before, and the heat to follow, Vanhelmont in his Treatie of Feavers Chap. 1. §. 5. Writes that the ick are ometimes troubled with cold alone, and experience alo witneeth the ame.

Hence unles we be egregiouly Deceived, we may infer with the uret Foundation, that the eence of Feavers conits not in heat (as many lead by peculation, more than by the verity of the matter, do boldly maintain) becaue then heat would be allways preent with the Feaver: neither could the Feaver be exitent without heat, which nevertheles,
they do, or may oberve daily, who leat of all attend to the practie of Phyick, do but viit the ick: I ay they may oberve in the beginning of mot intermitting Feavers, when the bodies of the ick are terrified and haken with cold, that cold alone is troubleome. Nevertheles, let it hould eem a new and unheard of thing, which we peak, that the Eence of Feavers doth not conit in heat, beides experience, we hall bring the Authority of Hypocrates which eems to teach the ame thing lib. De Vet. Med. Text. 30. 7. where he aith:
div.q: I think this to be the greatet ign that men do fall into Feavers not imply becaue of heat, neither is this imply the Caue of the affliction; but it is bitter and hot, and hot and acid, and alt and hot, and infinite other things; and again cold conjoyn'd with other faculties. Thee therefore are the things which hurt, &c.
div.p: But if any one notwithtanding be o captivated to his prejudices, that he denies a trembling and a horrour to be the beginning of intermitting Feavers, let him alo perwade himelf, as he mut, that thoe who at the time of that cold do die (as others have often een, and our elf alo within this eight days) expire without a feaver; which nevertheles to men converant in Phyick, will eem no les fale than ridiculous.

Perhaps no man will deny that in ome feavers, tertains epecially, no Cold being perceived, and by reaon of heat alone continually urging at the time of the fits, they may be called
burning feavers, and although any through a deire of Contradiction hould deny that burning, uch feavers will not therefore ceae to be oberved.

Foramuch as no feaver makes its progres alone, but for the mot part is accompanied with divers ymptomes, ome of which do torment the ick no les than the feaver it elf, they are ditinguihed, or at leatwie may be according to the diverity of ymptomes manifeting themelves with each fit into Syncopals, Hytericks, Colical, Raving, Greedy, Atmatical, Arthritical, Catharral, Emeticks, Catharticks, Salivals, &c. If any demand a Reaon, why the fits return one while daily, another every third day, another every fourth or fifth day, and that o certain as the hand of a Dial goes not more exactly? We hall ay that all the diverity depends, partly upon the diverity of obtructing phlegm, partly that of the tagnant Pancreatick Juice, for as there is found in the lateral Duct obtructed more or les pituity, and as it is more or les vicid, and the Pancreatick Juice more or les harp, o the pituity cauing the obtruction, will ooner or later be perforated by the Pancratick juice being made harp by tagnation.

And although the beginnings of fits mutually following one another, are not always ditant 24. 48. or 72. houres; but ometimes 18, ometimes 24, ometimes 30, ometimes 36, and 40 Houres, &c. Nevertheles Phiitians are wont to ditinguih the fits according
to daies; o that by quotidians they intend not only thoe which return every 24. houres, but thee alo which make their accees in 18. yea, 30 houres; the former of which they call Antiponents or going before, the later pot-ponents. [which word is generally undertood] So thoe fits which return every 48. houres are truly eteemed for tertians, but not thoe only; for they alo which are returned every 36. or 40. houres are called tertians, but anteponents, as alo thoe which are repeated every 50. 55. or 60. houres are called Tertians, and likewie Pot-ponents.

The Caue of this inequallity of the fits, eems to us to proceed from the obtructing phlegme being more or les vicid, or the whole Pancreatick Juice more or les harp, and that by reaon of the divere ue of the ix Non-naturals.

By this reaon it is not difficult to us to unfold how Quotidian feavers are changed into Tertians, and Tertians into Quartans, Quartans into Quintans, and the contrary; which thing they find very difficult, who determine that Quotidians arie from Phlegme, Tertians from Yellow Choler, and Quartans from Melancholy.

The Fits return o long, as the obtructing Pituity is not totally removed from the Duct, but remaining therein is again compelled to renew the Obtruction; But when the Vicid Phlegme, either of its own accord, or by art, is o evacuated, that nothing thereof remains,
which may be joyned together, whereby the obtruction may be renewed; then alo the Feavers are Cured. But as often as only one of the Lateral Ducts is obtructed, o often is one, and indeed a imple Feaver, produced. But as often, as many of the Lateral Ducts are obtructed together, o often are many and manifold Compound Feavers produced; which are either of the ame, or of a divere Species: Obtructions are of the ame Species, when they are of the ame Nature, and Pertinancy, in divere Ducts of the ame Magnitude. Obtructions are of a divere Species, when they are of a divere Nature, and Pertinancy, in divere Ducts, in like manner differing from one another in Magnitude. We ay in divere Ducts of the ame, or a divere Magnitude, eeing that as often as the Obtruction arieth from a like Pituity, in divere Ducts, of the ame Magnitude, and Amplitude: So often the Pancreatick Juyce, being made harp by tagnation, will, in an equal pace of time, perforate the obtructing Pituity; and alo, in an equal pace of time, will produce the Fit: But as often as Ducts, of a different Magnitude, and Amplitude, are equally obtructed by a Vicid Phlegme, o often hall we ee a Diverity in the Fits; in as much, as it may ooner, and more amply, wax harp, in one Duct, and thence the Fit may ooner return, and more grievouly afflict than in another; or as often as obtructions do happen in Ducts, of the ame Magnitude, from a Pituity, not
alike Vicid; o often, like-wie, may the Fits invade the Sick at divers times; for as much as the Pancreatick Juyce, equally waxing harp, will ooner perforate the les vicid pituity, than that which hath a greater Vicidity.

From thoe things, which we have now propounded, it will not be difficult to explain, How in a double Tertian, or other Compound Feavers, one Fit may, unexpectedly, come in an Hour or two, after another: For, the obtructions may happen in Ducts of the ame Magnitude, from a Pituity alike Vicid; o that, one obtruction may be excited the firt Hour, and another the fourth Hour; the which, if in Tertians, (unles ome fault, as we have aid, be committed in the ix Non naturals) the firt will again return on the third day, the firt hour, and the econd at the fourth Hour, &c. Which, in our judgement, affords no mall difficulty to thoe who hold, that Intermitting Feavers, are brought to a Turgecency, by Congetion, from an evil habit of the Blood, or of the Alimentary Juyce, depraved: as for example, eeing that the Alimentary Juyce, depraved, doth excite, by its Turgecency, a feaverih Effervecency in the Blood, in the firt Hour, Why may not that Quantity of the (depraved) Alimentary Juyce, erving to produce another Fit, which like-wie begins to well, in the ame Blood, being in the ame Effervecency, be enkindled, and conumed? Truly, we favour not that Opinion;
neither alo, can wee conceive how, in thoe which are fating, the Feaverih Fits o often, beyond meaure, could be returned at the ame time.

From what hath been aid, the reaon is alo manifet, wherefore in a double Tertian, or Quartane, &c. the fit doth preciely anticipate, or ucceed, an Hour; no other-wie, than as they arie from one, and the ame, Lateral Duct: For, as the whole Pancreatick Juyce, and the obtructing Pituity of both, grows more or les harp; alo, the Pituity of both, more or les Vicid: the Fits of both do equally return ooner or later. There are Feavers, whoe Species by ome, are difficultly ditinguihed; as for example, a Quotidian, from a double Tertian, or Triple Quartan; for, of thoe three Feavers, each daily excite one Fit; which ditinction, nevertheles creates no trouble to uch as are attentive to the matter: For, a Quotidian doth ordinarily invade the Sick, either at one Hour, or equally ooner, or later. The double Tertian, for the mot part, o hath its Fits, that the firt acces anwers to the third, and the econd to the fourth, &c. But in a Triple Quartan, the firt Fit anwereth to the fourth, and the econd to the fifth, &c.

Which things being rightly Conidered, every one may eaily ditinguih thee Feavers, mutually from one another, unles ome external fault diturb the order or frame of the Body,
either in whole or in part. The diverity of thoe Symptomes o variouly occurring, doth not overthrow thoe things which we have propounded concerning intermitting Feavers, epecially of heat and cold eeing that diverity dependeth upon a divere Contitution, of the ret of the Humours exitent in the Body. For otherwie a fit of a tertian Feaver, happening to a Body replenihed with much Bile, and that ufficiently harp, would lat far longer than a fit happening to that Body where but little bile, and that as yet temperate is remaining. Alo a greater or leer quantity of phlegme, as likewie plenty of other humours abounding in the body, may not a little augment this diverity.

But becaue it may not uffice to have aid, that the primary Symptomes of intermitting Feavers are heat and cold, it behoveth that we here alo, annex our Opinion concerning their Caue and Original We Judge that the cold of intermitting Feavers, draws its Original from the more acid Pancreatick Juice, and heat epecially from a more acrimonions Bile; the former is evinced by the aumption of acid things, as Galen proveth in a thouand places from things helping and hurting, that acids are cold, and do produce cold, and that not only in the ick, but alo in the ound; in which ometimes we ee alike Cold to have been excited, as thoe which are feaverih are wont to uffer, and any one may oberve, if acids be taken by thoe which are feaverih in the time of the cold fit,
that the feaverih cold will be encreaed after a wonderful manner. He that refueth to believe thee our obervations, let him read Galen De Simp. Med. Facult, where he aith: Every Acid, as it is only acid, is plainly cold; whether it be a Pear or an Apple, the Juice of Grapes or Rasberies, or Mulberies, punick Apples, or any other Fruit, or Juice, or Plants, as harp pointed Dock or Sorrel; for that it appears to the tat that there is a vehement Acidity inherent in it, neither may any thing be prefer'd before it; for its Acrimony, you hall find this Juice altogether cooling, &c. as alo in the ame Book Cap. 7. and in infinite other places he teacheth, that Acids are cold, and produce cold in our Bodies.

That the qualities of Humours are to be known by their effects, Hyppocrates Lib. De Vet. Med. Text. 39. 5. doth diligently inculcate: Know that the chief Forces of Humours is in their acid Faculty; which likewie in the 23. of the ame, from manifet things which behoveth to be Learned without the Body, he manifetly teacheth. Moreover, Lib. de Locis in Homine Text 56. 10. He aith, that Acids are alo pituitous, which in Lib. de Natura Humana Text. 12. 2. He manifetly declares to be mot cold of all things exiting in the Bodie: The which, unles it were true, untowardly would Galen in his whole Book concerning Food in acute Dieaes, and thoe who are his diligent followers, precribe an acid medicamentous Diet, in acute Feavers.

Although no man perhaps can eaily deny, heat to proceed from the Bile, in regard we ee that our natural heat is much augmented by the aumption of bitter, and aromatick Aliments and Sauces, augmenting Choler and making it more harp. Beides, both is proved by the Remedies exhibited, diminihing or taking away thoe Symptomes; For we ee clearly, that by medicines infringing the Acidity, the Cold is attempered and taken away; and we likewie oberve that by medicines tempering the Bile, epecially Acids, the heat is leened, as we hall preently in many things further Demontrate.

From whence every one may eaily imagine the Reaon, why for the mot part the fits of intermitting Feavers, are begun with a ence of Cold, and terminated with heat: For the Pancreatick Juice being made more harp by tagnation in one or more of the lateral Ducts; after which flowing into the thin Gut, there exciteth uch an effervecency with the Bile, wherein the Succus Pancreaticus by its predominant Acidity every way emits or ends forth acid Exhalations, affected with a ene of Cold; which when they touch the Gall-bladder by their acrimony provoke it to its Contraction, from whence the Bile breaking forth into the Intetine, in a more than uual quantity overwhelmes the Pancreatick Juice, and raieth therewith uch an Effervecency, in which the Bile predominating Excites heat, by ending every way its exhalations or Emiaries.

This our Opinion, is in a wonderful manner confirmed by the Vomitings, which very often happen to the Sick, at one time o cold and Acid, that bringeth a tupor to the Teeth; and again on the contrary, another while o hot and bitter, that they believe they Vomit nothing but pure Choler.

But ome perhaps may ask, why we deduce Vomitings and acid belchings, rather from the Pancreas, than from the Stomach? We anwer, becaue it is agreeable to experience, that the Pancreatick Juice is Acid, and eeing that the earchers of Nature, do as yet dipute concerning the ferment of the Stomach and its Generation, we judged that it ought to be determined, rather from a certain than an uncertain Caue: And if it hall be evinced by further earch in the tomach of Men (we peak not of Birds who require a tronger fermentation to diget Stones and other things of a hard conitency for the Generation of Shells) that any other ferment is generated, beides the Spittle continually wallowed, and that to be Acid, then hall we be o much the better able to prove an Effervecency to be excited in the thin Gut, between the Bile, and the Pancreatick Juice: Seeing that the Temperate, or Natural Acidity of the Pancreatick Juyce, would be helped by the acid Ferment of the Stomach; and from thence, the Effervecency would be the more powerfully performed.

It is further proved, that the Acidity, cat forth by Vomitting, doth not proceed from the Stomach, but from the Intetines, by Vomitories, exhibited out of the time of the Fit; by the help whereof, firt an inipid Matter, afterwards, by further training, an Acid, and Bilious Matter, is vomitted up; the contrary of which would happen, if the Soure, and Cholerick Matter, did proceed from the Stomach. Concerning the manner by which Acids may get to the Stomach, no man, of a ound mind, will doubt, who determines the Bile, ejected by Vomiting, to proceed from the Intetines: Seeing that the Pancreatick Juyce may, and ought to be driven through the ame wayes, as the Bile, flowing to the Intetines, by their inverted Peritaltick Motion, with the ame eae to the Ventricle, as we have above demontrated.

Neither doth the place a little confirm this our Opinion, in which, a Feaverih fit beginning, is for the mot part perceived Cold, then Hot; as alo, a mot fierce pain: We undertand the Region of the Loynes, in which the firt part of the thin Gut lies, under the Meentery, as is to be een Tab. I, wherein the Confux and Effervecency of the Bile, and the Pancreatick Juyce, is Celebrated; from which, the Particles of thoe Humours, being agitated upon the Ligaments of the Meentery, and other Nervous, and Membranous parts, they dah againt them, with an Impetuous force: So that, that Effervecency may ometimes
be perceived by the Touch in the Sick, as we have above demontrated. Nor does the Pancreatick Juyce, being made harp by tagnation, only exercie a tyranny, in the Region of the Loynes; but alo ends forth its acid Exhalations, both upwards and downwards; Who doubteth that from the one the Torments of the Belly, and from the other Acid belchings, do proceed? But if thoe Exhalations penetrate through the Venae Lacteae, to the Heart, by Incraating the Blood, gives an occaion of a leer Pule; which, nevertheles, by its corroding Acrimony, produceth one more frequent. The Acid Exhalations, being ubdued in manner afore-aid, Salt and Bilious Exhalations do follow; which again, by attenuating the Blood, do no les excite a great, and ometimes alo, a more frequent Pule, by irritating the Heart; and that o long till their Acrimony being pent, they can no longer irritate, or provoke the Heart: Which done, the Vigour and Natural pule of the Heart is returned: So that, very often the mot skilful can hardly judge, whether they have a Feaver or no.

We will not here peak (let this Chapter hould well too much, with that which we purpoed to finih in few Words) concerning ix Hundred other Symptomes, which are wont to accompany Intermitting Feavers; eeing we are perwaded there are none, at leat, of thoe who with an attent mind, have conidered, that the Juyce, or its Emiaries, after a
divere manner dipoed, doth perambulate the whole Body, and may produce divere Symptomes; but may, from thee things, deduce them by their own proper Indutry.

Which eeing it is o, we leaving thoe mall Circumtances, hall rightly pas on to the Cure of intermitting Feavers, which as it Primarily coniteth in taking away Obtructions, and correcting the Pancreatick Juice, and other Humours if they be Vitious; o it may be mot uccesfully performed, firt by Medicines inciding and attenuating tough Phlegme, and ometimes expelling it from the Body.
Secondly, By adhibiting Remedies, which are indued with a force of correcting and temperating the Pancreatick Juice, offending by its Acrimony.

Thirdly, By correcting other Humours in the Body, this or that way o peccant that they may Cherih the Vicious Effervecency excited in the thin Gut between the Bile and the Pancreatick Juice. For the taking away the Obtruction, temperating the more acid Pancreatick Juyce, and the diminihing the Cold, from thence proceeding, thee following Medicines do much conduce, viz. Water of Parly, Fennel, Baume, Simple Treacle-Water, Salt of Worm-wood, of Centary, the leer, Syrup of Carduus Benedicttus, or the five opening Roots, and the like, being mixed according to Art, epecially if taken halfe an hour before the feaverih Cold invades the Sick, who ought to be kept in his bed, or other warm place, that Sweat may
be a little promoted, or at leatwie that the operation of the Medicine may not be hindered.

We ay half an hour before the feaverih Cold invade the Sick, becaue Reaon teacheth, and Experience proveth, that cutting and attenuating, as unobtructing Medicaments do then with a far more happy Succes abolve that for which they are Adminitred, than if they were exhibited at any other time; the Reaon of which eemes to us, becaue thoe Medicines begin to operate at that time, wherein the Pancreatick Juice by its Acrimony doth molifie the Obtruction, and o by a united force, may more trongly and more happily diolve the Obtruction, than if either of thoe only were opperating: Moreover, It very much diminiheth the Feaverih Cold, which as yet would be performed with greater ucces, if to the mixture even now decribed, you hall add a drop or two of Oyl of Cloves, becaue as yet we ee no medicament that doth more powerfully take away Cold than that Oyle.

If a great Heat follow the feaverih Cold, to attemper that Medicines called Refrigeraters, among which aqueous things diluting the Bile eems to us mot agreeable, but epecially Acids with which the acrimony and volatillity of the aline Bile exceeding, producing Heat and burning is bet infringed. For as Doctor Minrotus aith pag. 36. in his Treatie of Malignant Feavers, Acids do
repres the inflamabillity of a Sulphurous Matter without the Body, o alo within the Body they bridle the inflaming Bile.

So Hippocrates, De Victu Acutor. Text. 29. 9. manifetly Teacheth that Acids do infringe and mitigate the Bile. And this is the Reaon, why the mot skilfullet Phyitians do daily precribe Acid Julips for the temperating of that feverih Heat; as for Example, by the Decoction of Barley, or coolling ditilled Waters with Syrup of Limmons, Mulberies, or Barberies, &c. By adding Spirit of Vitriol, Oyl of Sulpher per Capanum, or other Acid Spirits in a ufficient quantity to give it a grateful Acidity. For the ame end they alo ometimes precribe Apozems of the opening Roots, the Herb Sorrel, Lettice, the greater Houleek, Tamarinds, &c. by adding after the boyling, ome Acid Syrrups, and an acid Spirit ufficient for a grateful Acidity, that the ick may now and then take a mall Draught thereof to temperate the Heat.

If a great Thirt afflict the Feaverih at the time of Heat, half a Dram of Lap. Prunella may be conveniently diolved in the aforeaid Apozeme, or in mall Ale, or in a convenient Julip, for it excellently extinguiheth Thirt; and therefore thoe to whom Drink is hurtful, may diolve the ame Medicament in Water, but in a greater quantity, to wah the Mouth. Here it is well to be noted, that at the time of the Heat, it is not neceary that the Sick hould abtain
from moderate Drinking, which at the time of Cold is altogether required; becaue we daily ee, that if Drink be aumed at the time of the Cold fit, that it is augmented, and the Sick more troubled.

If the Medicaments, even now mentioned for Example, do not take away the Feaver, in the Intervals wherein they are not vexed with the Feaver, this following mixture will much avail. R. Fennel Water three Ounces, Simple Treacle Water ix Drams, ditilled Vinegar three Drams, Crabs Eyes prepared half a Dram, Syrup of the five opening Roots, half an Ounce mixt. Of which mot imple mixture, let one poonful be taken every two houres; for altering Medicines do operate far better if they be taken by Intervals, then if they be taken abundantly together and at once. If vehement Paines and Watchings do accompany the Feaver, Mixtures are to be ued in the Intervals, to which is added, one Grain of Laudanum Opiatum, which Medicament we do believe hath alo a force of temperating the accimony of the Humours, becaue we ee that Paines ariing from the Acrimony of Humours, remain not after Sleep procured by the prudent aumption of Laudanum Opiat; which in our Opinion could not happen, if that Laudanum had not a force of temperating harp Humours.

If a pain of the Head accompany the Feaver, in tead of fennel water, that of bettony, or burrage, may be ubtituted; and in
place of the Syrup of the five Roots, Syrup of Diacodium, or white Poppies. But if the Stomach be evilly affected, Water of Mint or of Carduus Benedictus will be ued with better ucces. If the menes flow not, Water of Peniroyal, Syrup of Mugwort, &c. may be exhibited. If a uffocation of the Womb be preent, in tead of thoe, may be added Spirit of Sal Ammoniack, Tinct of Cator, &c. if the Sick be tormented with flatulencies, Spirit of Nitre may be added; which remedy doth greatly help thoe which are troubled with a collick Paion, or any other flatulent Dieaes; epecially if ome Drops thereof be prudently mixed with ome Arromatick Waters, and the aforeaid Carminatives. If the Appetite be protrate by Reaon of too great a quantity of Bile carried to the Stomach, which will be known by the Appetite uddenly Detroyed, by bitter Belchings and Cholerick Vomitings, two Scruples of Elixir Proprietatis Paraceli may be added to the lat mixture. But if the aid evil proceedeth from a vicid pituity detained in the Stomach, which will be known by an aggravated pain in the Stomach, half a Dram of the dulcid Spirit of Salt intead of Elixir Proprietatis will be more Conducent if it be mixed with the foreaid mixture.

To the ame intent may be directed alo divers Apozemes, and other medicate Wines, Powders, Pills, and medicaments againt the aid Obtructions: Nevertheles you mut diligently
diligently Note, that Apozemes and other Medicaments epecially refrigerating which promicuouly they daily compel the Sick to wallow down in a great Doe, ometimes o debillitate their Stomacks that the Appetite is thereby not only Detroyed, but ometimes fall into a didain or Loathing of Aliments, from whence a new Affliction is added to the Sick, and the latter Errour is allo very often wore than the firt. But if notwithtanding before the Phyician hath attained his deired end, he thinketh ome other Humour doth offend by too much plenty, that may be diminihed with convenient medicines.

The Diet according to the diverity of intermitting Feavers, mut ometimes be changed, becaue Tertian Feavers accompanied with the greatet Heat, do require a Diet more Cooling than Quartans which very often afflict the Sick with intollerable Cold and Trembling: For we ee the moderate ue of French Wine, which we are wont to forbid in all Tertians, omtimes to be granted in Quartans. But uch a Diet as may be agreeable to all intermitting Feavers, every one may gather from what we have already poken.

We would have further propounded ome other Remedies as well accomodated to intermitting Feavers as to their Symptomes, had not the mot Famous Doctor Sylvius in the
firt Part of his Praxis already Printed, propoed many, and the mot excellent of them.
From my Study, Feb. 2d. 167 5/6. at the Signe of the Globe, and Chymical Furnaces, in the Potern, near Moor-Gate, London.

div.head: POST-SCRIPT.
div.p:
I Have taken notice of many People (epecially of the Poorer ort) who are afflicted with tedious Agues, and many more, who labour under thoe Deplorable Fits, commonly called the Fits of the Mother, and Spleen; as alo, the Falling Sicknes, Grievous Convulions, &c. And being well atisfied, (as well by the means of Curation, as the undenyable Experiments, and valid Reaons in this Book, confirming the ame) that thoe Dieaes, with many more, derive their Original from the Vitious Alteration of this Juyce, of the Sweet-Bread: I, for the ake of poor People, that they might have help at an eaie Rate, hereby let them know, that (amongt many other) I have two Medicines, which are certain in the Cure of the fore-mentioned Dieaes. The one will diolve the Conjunct Matter of all Ague-Fits, with great Celerity; it being of uch Subtile Parts, that it quickly penetrateth, and openeth thoe Obtructions in the Lateral Branches of the Pancreas, or Sweet-Bread, from whence thoe Agues proceed. The which Medicine alone (with the help of a proper Purge, to carry off the Matter after it is diolved, and attenuated) will, in a hort time, Cure the Fits of any Ague whatoever. It is put up in Glaes,
and old at the Price of half a Crown each Glae, with Directions for the ue thereof; one Glae being ufficient for the Cure of an Ague that is but of a hort Continuance.

The other Medicine is a Specifick Remedy, againt the Fits of the Mother, Hypocondriack Paines, and Melancholy, Vapours ariing (as is generally aid) from the Spleen, and Womb: As alo, againt Convulion Fits, Falling Sicknes, and Vertigoe, or Giddines of the Head: In which Caes, thoe who have made frequent ue thereof, have found it to anwer their Intention. This is alo old at half a Crown a Glas, with Directions for its e. Thee Medicines are old at my own Houe, and at no other Place; Where alo may be had all Chymical Medicines in ue, truly prepared; uch as are afe, and effectual in Operation, and able to abide the Tet of the mot Curious Examiners: This being added for the Information of Phyitians, Chyrurgions, and Apothecaries, who may have occaion to make e thereof.
From my Houe at the Signe of the Globe, and Chymical-Furnaces, in the Potern-Street, near Moor-Gate, Feb. 16th. 167 5/5.
